POLICE DEPARTMENT
Article I General Provisions
Section 4 -101 Creation. There is hereby created a Police Department, an executive department of
the Village, consisting of the Police Chief and such other members of the department as may be
appointed by the Village Manager or the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
Section 4 -102 Duties of Members of Police Department. It shall be the duty ofthe members of the
Police Department to enforce all ordinances of the Village and all statutes of the State of Illinois
effective in the Village, and to arrest all violators thereof. Every member of the Police Department is
hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace and shall have the powers granted by law to such
conservators of the peace.
a. All warrants for the violation of any provisions of this Code or the State criminal law, to
whomsoever directed, may be served and executed within the limits of the Village by any
member of the Police Department. For this purpose, members of the Police Department have
all the common law statutory power of constables.
b. Members of the Police Department shall have power and authority, in a peaceable and quiet
manner, to enter any house, building or on any premise in the Village, in which the police
reasonably expect to find therein any person who is there for any unlawful purpose. If any
person shall be found therein, guilty of any crime, misdemeanor, or violating any provision
of this Code or any other ordinance for the preservation of peace and good order of the
Village, or who may reasonably be suspected thereof, or who shall be aiding and abetting
such person so doing, they shall apprehend and keep in custody such person, as in cases of
other arrests.
Ord. # 12- 013)
Section 4 -103 Office of Police Chief Created. There is hereby created the office of Police Chief.
The Chief shall be appointed by, and shall serve at the discretion of, the Village Manager. The Chief
need not be a member of the Police Department at the time of appointment. The Chief shall receive
such salary as may be set by the Village Manager after consultation with the President and Board of
Trustees.
Section 4 -104 Duties of the Chief. The Chief shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the Police
Department, responsible for the administration of the Police Department, the performance of all its
functions and for all the members of the Department.
a. The Chiefmay make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the guidance ofthe members
of the Department as deemed necessary.
b. The Chief shall be responsible for the training and conduct of the members of the
Department.
C. The Chief shall be keeper of the Village jail and shall have custody of all persons
incarcerated therein.
d. The Chief shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of the
Department as may be required by any statute, this Code or the Village Manager.
2 REVISED 03/ 19/ 12
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
e. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Chief shall take the oath of office prescribed by
statute for municipal officers.
Ord. # 15 -020)
Section 4 -105 Office of Deputy Chief Created. There is hereby created the office ofDeputy Chief.
The Deputy Chief shall be appointed by, and shall serve at the discretion of, the Village Manager.
The appointment to Deputy Chief shall be filled by a current member ofthe Police Department, from
the ranks of Commander, Lieutenant and Sergeant only. Compensation for the Deputy Chief shall be
determined in accordance with the current Village pay plan.
Ord. # 06 -025, # 15 -020)
Section 4 -106 Duties of the Deputy Chief. Each Deputy Chief shall be responsible for the control
and direction of activities for one division of the Police Department. As needed, one of the Deputy
Chiefs shall be designated to be the second executive officer in command of the Police Department
and shall assist the Police Chief in administration of the Police Department. During the absence or
disability of the Police Chief, one of the Deputy Chiefs shall perform the duties of the Chief.
Section 4 -107 Office of Police Commander Created. There is hereby created the office ofPolice
Commander. The Police Commander shall be appointed by, and shall serve at the discretion of, the
Village Manager. The appointment to Police Commander shall be filled by a current member of the
Arlington Heights Police Department, from the rank of Sergeant only. Compensation for the Police
Commander shall be determined in accordance with the current Village pay plan.
Section 4 -108 Property Processed by Police Department: Chief to be Custodian. The Police
Chief shall be the custodian of all lost, abandoned or recovered stolen property in the Village and all
property which may be seized or otherwise taken possession of by the Police Department of the
Village.
Section 4 -109 Disposition of Unclaimed Property. Ifproperty seized or taken possession ofby the
Police Department, as provided in Section 4 -108 shall not be claimed by the rightful owner within 90
days from the date of the final disposition of the court proceedings in connection with which such
property was seized or otherwise taken possession of, or in the case there are no such court
proceedings, then if such property so seized or taken possession surrendered to such owner within 90
days after the date which the Police Department obtains such possession, the Police Chief shall cause
the property to be sold for cash to the highest bidder at a public auction and the proceeds to be
deposited with the Village Treasurer.
a. The Police Chief shall cause to be published, in a newspaper of general circulation in the
county, a description of all property to be sold (including the time and place of sale) together
with the date of seizure or the taking possession thereof and shall give notice that if such
property is not claimed by the rightful owner or owners thereofwithin ten days from the date
of such publication, the property will be sold at public auction.
b. In addition to the publication of notice provided for in this section, the Police Chief shall post
or cause to be posted in at least three public places in the Village, a copy of the notice
published in the newspaper and shall make a record of the date when such publication and
the posting of notices are made and if, within ten days from the date of such publication and
3 REVISED 07/ 06/ 15
POLICE DEPARTMENT
posting, no claim for such property described in such notices shall have been made by the
rightful owner thereof, shall proceed to sell such property at public auction.
C. No Village employees directly or indirectly shall purchase or participate in the bidding for or
purchase of any unclaimed property.
If any person shall deposit with the Police Department money or any other personal property
of value which has been found or otherwise come into the lawful possession of such person
without ownership, the Police Department may receive and hold such property in
safekeeping. The party delivering such property shall receive a receipt indicating the date the
property is received and the nature of the property. If the rightful owner does not claim such
property within 90 days, the property shall be returned to the person who delivered the
property to the Police Department. Any claim to such property by person other than those
who delivered the property to the Police Department shall be supported by affidavit and such
other suitable evidence as may be required by the Police Chief to establish the fact that the
claimant is indeed the rightful owner. Neither the Police Chief nor any other police officer
shall be liable in any action in law or equity for delivering the property to a person who has
established his claim to the property to the satisfaction of the Police Chief.
Ord. # 12 - 028, # 15 -020)
Section 4 -110 Appointment and Compensation of Members. All regular members of the Police
Department except the Chief, Deputy Chiefs, and Police Commanders shall be appointed by the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. They shall be employees of the Village.
Ord. # 97 -069)
All appointments of police officers shall be for a probationary period of 18 months. If, at the
expiration of that time, the applicant, in the opinion of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners,
proves to be fit for the position, he shall be permanently certified to the position by the Board. If, in
the judgment of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, he shall prove unsatisfactory at the
expiration of 18 months, he shall be dropped from the service. Provided, however, that if the Village
hires a Certified Entry Candidate, as defined by the Rules of the Village Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners, such candidate shall serve a probationary period of 12 months, unless extended
because of an employee' s extended absence from work during the employee' s first 12 months of
employment.
Ord. # 01 - 068, # 12 - 028)
Section 4 -111 Conduct of Members; Suspension. It shall be the duty of every member of the
Police Department to conduct himself in a proper and law- abiding manner, and to avoid the use of
unnecessary force. He shall not behave in any manner which is a discredit to the Police Department
or in any way be guilty of conduct unbecoming a police officer. He shall promptly obey all lawful
orders from his superiors and maintain his uniform, equipment and person in a neat and orderly
condition. He shall pay his debts promptly and not be seen in the company of, or associate with,
persons of doubtful or questionable character. He shall obey and abide by the rules and regulations
promulgated by the Police Chief and the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
The Police Chief shall have the power to suspend any police officer from duty for a period not to
exceed 30 days. The suspension may be made with or without pay by the Chief, and any person
4 REVISED 07/ 06/ 15
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
suspended without pay shall not be entitled to pay while so suspended, nor until he shall be returned
to duty.
Section 4 -112 Witness Fees. Every member of the Police Department shall appear as a witness
whenever this is necessary in a prosecution for a violation of a Village ordinance or a State or
Federal law. But no such member shall receive any witness fee for such services in any action or suit
to which the Village is a parry; all fees due for such services shall, if paid, be turned over to the
Village Treasurer.
Section 4 -113 Special Police Officers. The Village Manager may appoint any reputable person as a
special police officer to serve for such term and on such conditions as may be designated by the
terms of such appointment. Special police officers shall have the powers and duties of a conservator
ofthe peace, and shall receive such compensation as may be provided by the President and Board of
Trustees. Appointments may be revoked at any time by the Village Manager.
Article II Jail
Section 4 -201 Establishment. The place in the Village heretofore established and used for aj ail, or
any other place which may be hereafter used for that purpose, is hereby declared to be the Village
jail.
Section 4 -202 Keeper. The Police Chief shall be the keeper of the jail and shall have custody over
all persons confined therein and of all property pertaining thereto.
Section 4 -203 Prisoners. The jail shall be used for the incarceration of all persons arrested for
violating any laws of the State of Illinois, the United States, or for violating any Village ordinance
until such person shall be lawfully brought before a magistrate for a hearing or until such person
shall be lawfully transferred to some other place of incarceration or lawfully released.
Section 4 -204 Escape. It shall be unlawful for any person to escape or attempt to escape, or to
assist any prisoner to escape or attempt to escape from jail.
Section 4 -205 Communication with Prisoners. It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate
with any prisoner held in the jail without the permission of the Police Chief or the police officer in
charge.
Section 4 -206 Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision ofthis Article shall
be fined not less than $ 5 nor more than $ 750 for each offense.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT
2 REVISED 03/19/12
Article I General Provisions
Section 5-101 Creation. There is hereby created a Fire Department, an executive department of the
Village. The Fire Department shall consist of the Fire Chief and such other members of the
department as may be provided for from time to time by the Board of Police and Fire
Commissioners.
Section 5-102 Duties of Members of Fire Department. It shall be the function and duty of the Fire
Department and every member thereof to extinguish accidental or destructive fires and to prevent the
occurrence or spread of such fires. Any fireman in attendance at a fire shall obey the orders of the
officer in command at such a fire.
a. It shall be the duty of all members of the Fire Department to enforce all the Fire Prevention
regulations of this Code, and all other Code provisions falling within the competence of the
Fire Department. For this purpose, the members of the Fire Department are hereby vested
with the usual powers and authority of police officers.
b. In case of fire, the officer at the fire with the highest rank shall take command of the Fire
Department and direct its activities in order to suppress the fire in the best manner to the Fire
Department.
c. When it may be necessary for the protection of other property and to prevent the spread of
the conflagration, the officer in command may cause buildings to be removed, torn down or
destroyed in the best manner possible.
d. All members of the Fire Department shall perform such other duties as are required of them
by this Code or by such other rules and regulations of the Board of Police and Fire
Commissioners now or hereafter in force pertaining in any manner to the Fire Department.
Ord. #12-013)
Section 5-103 Office of Fire Chief Created. There is hereby created the Office of Fire Chief. The
Fire Chief shall be appointed by, and shall serve at the discretion of, the Village Manager. The Chief
need not be a member of the department at the time of appointment. He shall receive such
compensation as may be set by the Village Manager after consultation with the President and Board
of Trustees.
Section 5-104 Duties of the Chief. The Fire Chief shall have the control, subject to the order and
direction of the Village Manager, of the Fire Department and all fire apparatus belonging to the
Village.
a. He shall be responsible for the training and conduct of members of the department, and may
make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members of the
department as he shall deem necessary.
b. Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Chief shall take the oath of office prescribed
by statute for municipal officers.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
5-3 REVISED 09/15/14
Section 5-105 Office of Deputy Fire Chief Created. There is hereby created the office of Deputy
Fire Chief. The Deputy Fire Chief shall be appointed by and shall serve at the discretion of the
Village Manager. He shall be a member of the Fire Department at the time of his appointment and
shall retain his classification at the time of appointment under the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners. The Deputy Fire Chief shall serve in the place and stead of the Fire Chief when the
Fire Chief is absent or otherwise incapacitated. He shall perform such other duties and functions as
may be assigned to him by the Fire Chief. He shall receive such additional compensation over and
above the compensation for his permanent rank as may be provided from time to time by the
President and Board of Trustees in the annual budget. The salary for pension purposes shall be the
total compensation by the Deputy Fire Chief.
Ord. #99-008, #14-047)
Section 5-106 Offices of Battalion Chief and Division Chief Created. There is hereby created
within the Fire Department, the offices of Battalion Chief and Division Chief. The Battalion Chiefs
and Division Chiefs shall be appointed by and shall serve at the discretion of the Village Manager.
The appointment to Battalion Chief or Division Chief shall be filled by a current member of the
Arlington Heights Fire Department, from the rank of Lieutenant only. Compensation for the
Battalion Chiefs and Division Chiefs shall be shall be determined in accordance with the current
Village pay plan.
Ord. #96-022, #96-044, # 12-028, #14-047)
Section 5-107 Appointment and Compensation of Members. All regular members of the Fire
Department, except the Chief, Deputy Chief, Battalion Chief and Division Chief, shall be appointed
by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. They shall be employees of the Village.
All appointments of firemen, below the rank of officer, shall be for a probationary period of one year.
If, at the expiration of that time, the applicant, in the opinion of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners, proves to be fit for the position, he shall be permanently certified to the position by
the Board. If, in the judgment of the Board, he shall prove unsatisfactory at the expiration of one
year, he shall be dropped from the service.
Section 5-108 Conduct of Members; Suspension. It shall be the duty of every member of the Fire
Department to conduct himself in a proper and law abiding manner. He shall not behave in any
manner which is a discredit to the Fire Department or in any way guilty of conduct unbecoming a
member of the Fire Department. He shall promptly obey all lawful orders of his superiors and
maintain his uniform, equipment and person in a neat and orderly condition. He shall pay his debts
promptly and not be seen in the company of, or associate with, persons of doubtful or questionable
character. He shall obey and abide by the rules and regulations promulgated by the Fire Chief and
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
Section 5-109 Inspection of Buildings. Members of the Fire Department upon complaint or when
deemed necessary, shall inspect all buildings and premises within the Village. Whenever said
members shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repairs, lack of or insufficient
fire escapes or fire alarm apparatus or fire extinguishing equipment or byreason of age or dilapidated
condition, or from any other cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger
other property or the occupants thereof, and whenever such officer shall find in any building
combustible or explosive matter or flammable conditions dangerous to the safety of such building or
the occupants thereof, he or they shall order such dangerous conditions or materials to be removed or
remedied and such order shall forthwith be complied with bythe owner or occupant of such premises
THE FIRE DEPARTMENT

or building. The Fire Chief or any member of the Fire Department may at all reasonable hours enter
any building or premises within the Village for the purpose of making any inspection or investigation
under the provisions of the ordinances of the Village of Arlington Heights as may be deemed
necessary to be made.

BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
2 REVISED 05/06/96
Article I General Provisions
Section 6-101 Purpose and Intent. This Chapter contains the enabling legislation for all boards
and commissions appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. Also included are articles pertaining to Boards of Trustees of Pension Funds and to the
Board of Library Directors, which are exempt from these general provisions.
Section 6-102 Meeting Dates.
a. All boards and commissions appointed by the Board of Trustees shall meet at least quarterly,
unless a specific exemption is set forth by the Board of Trustees. Currently exempted from
quarterly meetings are:
1. Board of Health;
2. Electrical Commission;
3. Fire and Police Commission;
4. Redevelopment Commission;
5. Building Code Review Board.
b. All meeting dates and places shall be announced in advance, usually by means of the Village
Weekly Calendar, in compliance with the Illinois Open Meeting Law.
Section 6-103 Meetings with Village Board.
Ord. #96-030)
a. Boards and commissions shall meet as needed with the Village Board, meeting as a
Committee-of-the Whole.
b. When a Village Board decision results in the need for action by a board or commission or
contains information pertinent to its activities and responsibilities, the Village Manager will
ensure its prompt conveyance to the staff liaison for that board or commission and the chair
of the board or commission involved.
Section 6-104 Change of Compensation of Boards and Commissions. Any ordinance providing
for a change in the compensation of any board or commission shall be adopted no less than 120 days
nor more than 150 days prior to the date set for the election of Village Trustees.
Section 6-105 Procedures for Appointing Members.
a. Each person applying for or expressing a willingness to serve on a board or commission shall
provide a resume to the Village President.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
3 REVISED 05/06/96
Ord. #96-030)
b. Individuals appointed by the Village President to boards and commissions will be referred to
the Committee-of-the-Whole of the Board of Trustees for interviews. Following interviews
of new appointees, their names shall be placed on the agenda of the next regular meeting of
the Board of Trustees, at which time the Board gives its advice or consent to the
appointment. Individuals designated by the Village President to be reappointed to the boards
or commissions will be announced on the “ Consent Agenda”, and resumes provided to all
trustees for the Board to give its advice or consent.
c. Appointees are provided written notification by the Village Administration of their
appointment. At the same time, each appointee is provided applicable local ordinances, State
Statutes, oath of office, ethics statement and other administrative information and
instructions.
Ord. #96-030)
Section 6-106 Procedures for Designating Chairs. Individuals designated by the Village
President to be chairs of boards or commissions will be announced on the "Consent Agenda," and
resumes provided to all trustees for the Board to give its advice or consent.
Section 6-107 Oath of Office. An appointee is qualified to vote as a member of a board or
commission only after having been administered the oath of office. The oath shall be administered at
the first regular meeting of the Board of Trustees following the confirmation of the appointment or
by the Village Clerk at a mutually convenient time. The Village Clerk will maintain on file a record
of all oaths of office.
Section 6-108 Ethics Statement. The Village policy pertaining to ethics is contained in Chapter 1
of this Code. It prescribes, among other things, that all elected and appointed officials file a
disclosure statement with the Village Clerk on appointment, not later than the administration of the
oath of office, and on or before May 1 of each year.
Section 6-109 Attendance at Meetings.
a. It is the obligation of each member of a board or commission to attend all meetings. In the
event of illness or unavoidable absence, it is the responsibility of the member to notify the
chair.
b. Acommittee member who misses three consecutive meetings is required to submit a written
explanation to the chair of the board or commission.
c. The Village President is authorized to initiate removal procedures under applicable law in
circumstances where no written explanation of absences is provided.
Ord. #96-030)
Section 6-110 Liaison Committee. The Committee-of-the Whole of the Village Board of Trustees
shall perform as liaison to monitor the activities of the appointed boards and commissions.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
4
Section 6-111 Resignations. Members of boards and commissions who find it necessary to resign
shall notify the chair and address a letter of resignation to the Village President. Copies of all letters
of resignation shall be furnished to all members of the Board of Trustees.
Section 6-112 Proceedings.
a. Chairs of boards and commissions shall conduct business in accordance with procedures
approved by the Board of Trustees. Meetings shall be conducted in accordance with Robert's
Rules of Order unless otherwise provided for in approved procedures.
b. Matters of policy shall be approved by the Board of Trustees. In this regard, the use of
Village stationery will be in accordance with current Board of Trustees policy.
c. The Village Manager will provide secretarial assistance to boards and commissions as
required.
d. All meetings will be held in a public building, usually the Village Hall, unless authorized by
the Board of Trustees.
e. Meeting agendas will be arranged so as to conclude all meetings by 10:30 P.M. Boards and
Commissions shall establish rules for extending meetings beyond 10:30 P.M.
Section 6-113 Staff Liaison. The Village Manager shall designate a staff liaison for each Board
and Commission. These staff liaisons shall advise and provide technical support to the Boards and
Commissions under the direction of the Village Manager.
Article II Appointive Boards and Commissions with Statutory Authority
Section 6-201 Plan Commission. There is hereby created a Plan Commission as provided by
Statute.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, fact-finding, advisory body which shall,
after due deliberation and public hearing, when required, make recommendations to the
Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to:
1. The Comprehensive Plan and Official Map;
2. Chapter 28 - Zoning Regulations;
3. Chapter 29 - Subdivision Regulations;
4. Individual Petitions pertaining to the above;
5. Such other matters as may be referred to the Plan Commission by the Village Board.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
6-5 REVISED 10/07/19
b. Members. The Plan Commission shall consist of nine members, residents of the Village,
appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Plan Commission shall serve terms of three years or until their
successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. Terms of appointment shall be
staggered. Not more than one-third of the members shall be appointed in any one year unless
required by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually, the
Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one
of the members of the Plan Commission to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more
than three consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that continued service
as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
Ord. #19-034)
d. Compensation. Members of the Plan Commission shall serve without compensation.
Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel Regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Plan Commission shall have such powers, duties
and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, including
those enumerated below:
1. The Comprehensive Plan and Official Map. The Plan Commission shall have the
power and responsibility to annually review the Village Comprehensive Plan
Comprehensive Plan") and Map ("Official Map"). The Comprehensive Plan is a
description of long-range public policy affecting community character, economic
well-being, cultural and social amenities, ease and convenience of circulation in the
Village, and orderly development of various land uses and serves as a policy guide in
all decisions related to community growth. The Official Map identifies the location
of present and future public service facilities and improvements, thoroughfare system
improvements, park and school sites and land for other public purposes.
a) The Comprehensive Plan and Official Map shall be applicable to all land
situated within the corporation limits and all contiguous territory not more
than one and one-half miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in
any municipality.
b) The Comprehensive Plan and Official Map shall be advisory and shall not be
construed to regulate or control the use of private property in any way except
as to such part thereof as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted
by the Board of Trustees.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-6
c) No amendment or change to the Comprehensive Plan or Official Map shall be
adopted that has not been submitted to the Plan Commission.
d) No recommendation for amendment to the Comprehensive Plan or Official
Map shall be made by the Plan Commission until notice and opportunity for
hearing have been afforded and all other provisions of State Statutes have
been satisfied.
e) The Plan Commission shall be responsible for annual review of the
Comprehensive Plan and Official Map. Each year, no later than December 31,
the Plan Commission shall report to the Village Board of Trustees, including
any recommended amendments or shall recommend no changes.
2. Zoning Regulations. The Plan Commission shall, upon direction from the Board of
Trustees or at its own initiative, review any part of Chapter 28 (Zoning Regulations),
hold appropriate public hearings and make recommendations to the Board of
Trustees.
3. Subdivision Control Recommendations. The Plan Commission shall, upon direction
om the Board of Trustees or at its own initiative, review any part of Chapter 29
Subdivision Control Regulations), hold appropriate public hearings and make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees.
4. Individual Zoning, Subdivision and Development Petitions. The Plan Commission
will conduct appropriate hearings, unless a majority of the Trustees directs that a
specific hearing be held in some other manner, and submit recommendations to the
Board of Trustees on petitions involving the following matters:
a) Subdivision and Resubdivision;
b) Special Uses;
c) Planned Unit Developments;
d) Rezoning;
e) Variations to the extent allowed in Chapters 28 and 29;
f) Other matters referred to the Commission by the Board of Trustees.
5. Organization of the Plan Commission. The Plan Commission maycreate subcommittees
and adopt policies and procedures deemed advisable to fulfill its powers, duties
and responsibilities. All such policies and procedures shall be recorded and
submitted to the Board of Trustees.
6. General Guidelines. The Plan Commission, in all its proceedings, shall:
a) Be consistent with statutes of the State of Illinois.
b) Be consistent with the Municipal Code, with particular reference to the intent
and purpose of this Section and Chapters 28 and 29. Variations may be
recommended to the extent provided for by the Code or to the extent that
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
6-7 REVISED 10/07/19
there is a reasonable interpretation of the provisions of the Code, provided
such variations are clearly identified and justified.
c) Take cognizance of all official policy documents pertaining to planning,
zoning and subdivision. Variations may be recommended only when clearly
identified and justified.
Ord. #06-071)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Plan Commission shall be held at the
call of the Chair. Special meetings may be called by the Village President, the Board of
Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the Plan Commission
or a quorum of the Plan Commission. Five members shall constitute a quorum. The Chair
shall vote with other members of the Commission.
g. Records and Reports. The Plan Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings,
which records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-202 Zoning Board of Appeals. There is hereby created a Zoning Board of Appeals as
provided by Statute.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, fact-finding body which shall, after due
deliberation and public hearing, make final decisions on specified administrative matters
related to zoning.
b. Members. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall consist of seven members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall serve terms of five years or until
their successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. Terms of appointment shall
be staggered. Not more than two of the members shall be appointed in any one year unless
required by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually, the
Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one
of the members of the Zoning Board of Appeals to be chair. No person shall serve as chair
more than three consecutive years unless the Village President determines that continued
service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
Ord. #19-034)
d. Compensation. Members of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall serve without compensation.
Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel Regulations.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-8 REVISED 10/18/04
Ord. #04-059, #18-010)
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall have the powers,
duties and responsibilities assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, including
those enumerated below:
1. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall adopt its own rules of procedure not in conflict
with the Code or with the Illinois Statutes.
2. Jurisdiction. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall have the following powers and
duties:
a) To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is an error in any order,
requirement, decision or determination made by the Building Commissioner
or appropriate Administrative Officer in the enforcement of the Code, or to
hear and decide any of the appeals provided for in this Section.
b) In hearing and deciding appeals, the Zoning Board of Appeals shall have the
power to:
1) Permit the extension of a district where the boundary line of a district
divides a lot or tract held in a single ownership at the time of the
passage of the Zoning Ordinance.
2) Interpret the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance in such a way as to
carry out the intent and purpose of the plan, as shown on the map
fixing the several districts, accompanying and made a part of the
Zoning Ordinance, where the street layout actually on the ground
varies from the street layout as shown on the map aforesaid.
3) Permit the erection and use of a building or the use of premises for
railroad or public utility purposes, in accordance with the " Special
Uses" section of Chapter 28 of this Code.
4) Permit the reconstruction of a non-conforming building which has
been damaged by explosion, fire, act of God or public enemy, to the
extent of more than 50% of its value, where the Board finds some
compelling necessity which requires a continuance of the nonconforming
use and the primary purpose of continuing the nonconforming
use is not to continue a monopoly.
5) Waive the established parking requirements whenever the character
or use of the building is such as to make unnecessary the full
provision of parking facilities, or where such regulations would
impose an unreasonable hardship upon the use of the lot, as
contrasted with merely granting an advantage of convenience.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
6-9 REVISED 04/16/18
6) Permit land within 200 feet of a multiple dwelling to be improved for
the parking spaces required in connection with the multiple dwelling,
but only when there is positive assurance that such land will be used
for such purpose during the existence of the multiple dwelling.
7) Permit a variation in the yard requirements of any district where there
are unusual and practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the
carrying out of these provisions due to an irregular shape of the lot,
topographical or other conditions, provided such variation will not
seriously affect any adjoining property or the general welfare.
8) Permit a limited increase in the number of employees permitted in
processing activities in the Business, Commercial or Industrial
Districts, but only when such increase will not adversely affect the
commercial character of the establishment, will not be detrimental to
or adversely affect the character of surrounding residential
development, or will not seriously increase traffic or parking
congestion on adjoining streets.
Ord. #18-010)
c) Authorize upon appeal, whenever a property owner can show that a strict
application of the terms of the Zoning Ordinance relating to the construction
or alteration of building or structures will impose upon the owner unusual
practical difficulties or particular hardship, such variation of the strict
application of the terms of the Zoning Ordinance as are in harmony with its
general purposes and intent, but only when the Board is satisfied that a
granting of such variation will not merely serve as a convenience to the
applicant, but will alleviate some demonstrable and unusual hardship or
difficulty so great as to warrant a variation from the Comprehensive Plan, and
at the same time the surrounding property will be properly protected.
In its consideration of the standards of practical difficulties or particular
hardship, the Board of Appeals shall require evidence that:
1) The proposed use will not alter the essential character of the locality
and will be compatible with existing uses and zoning of nearby
property; and
2) The plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances, which may
include the length of time the subject property has been vacant as
zoned; and
3) The proposed variation is in harmony with the spirit and intent of this
Chapter;
4) The variance requested is the minimum variance necessary to allow
reasonable use of the property.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-10 REVISED 04/16/18
d) Nothing contained herein shall be construed to give or grant to the Zoning
Board the power or authority to alter or change the Zoning Ordinance or the
District Map, that power and authority being reserved to the Board of
Trustees. Decisions by the Zoning Board shall be final administrative
decisions.
3. In exercising the above powers, the Board may reverse, affirm or modify the order,
requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and to that end shall have all
the powers of the Administrative Officer from whom the appeal is taken.
4. The Zoning Board shall not make any recommendation except in a specific case and
after it conducts a public hearing. A notice of the time and place of the public
hearing shall be published in a paper of general circulation in the Village at least 15
but not more than 30 days previous to the hearing. Such notice shall contain the
address or location of the property for which the variation or other rule of the Board
is sought, as well as a brief description of the nature of the appeal.
5. No order of the Board permitting the erection or alteration of a building shall be valid
for more than one year, unless a building permit for the erection or alteration is
obtained within that year and the erection or alteration is started and proceeds to
completion in accordance with the terms of such permit. No order of the Zoning
Board permitting a use of a building or premises shall be valid for more than one
year, unless the use is established within that year; provided, however, that where the
use permitted is dependent upon the erection or alteration of a building, the order
shall continue in force and effect if a building permit for the erection or alteration is
obtained within that year and the erection or alteration is started and proceeds to
completion in accordance with the terms of such permit.

6-11 REVISED 07/06/09
Ord. #06-071)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be held
at the call of the Chair. Special meetings may be called by the Village President, the Board
of Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the Zoning Board
of Appeals or a quorum of the Zoning Board of Appeals. Four members shall constitute a
quorum. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Board.
g. Records and Reports. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall keep written records of its
proceedings, which records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-203 Board of Health. There is hereby created a Board of Health as provided by Statute.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, fact-finding body which shall make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to health. Additionally, the
Board of Health shall take emergency actions authorized by Statute, such as quarantine, to
protect the public health.
b. Members. The Board of Health shall consist of five members, residents of the Village and
health care professionals, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. The Executive Vice-President of Northwest Community
Hospital shall serve as ex-officio member of the Board of Health.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Board of Health shall serve terms of three years or until their
successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. Terms of appointment shall be
staggered. Not more than two of the members shall be appointed in any one year unless
required by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually, the
Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one
of the members of the Board of Health to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than
three consecutive years unless the Village President determines that continued service as
chair is in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Board of Health shall serve without compensation.
Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel Regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Board of Health shall have such powers, duties
and responsibilities as are assigned by the Board of Trustees, including the following:
1. The Board of Health shall adopt its own rules or procedure not in conflict with the
Code or with the Illinois Statutes. The Board of Health may propose rules and
regulations for the protection of health in the Village to guard against the spread of
contagious diseases and to prevent, by necessary rules, the reduction of diseases,
contagious or otherwise, within the corporate limits of the Village.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-12 REVISED 10/07/19
2. The Board of Health shall have the powers and perform the duties assigned to it by
Statute or by the provisions of this Code.
3. The Board of Health may propose reasonable rules regarding vaccination for the
prevention of the spread of contagious diseases and to quarantine premises where
such diseases occur or for such time necessary to protect the public health.
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Board of Health shall be held at the call
of the Chair. Special meetings maybe called by the Village President, the Board of Trustees,
the Liaison Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the Board of Health, or a
quorum of the Board of Health. Three members shall constitute a quorum. The Chair shall
vote with other members of the Board of Health.
g. Records and Reports. The Board of Health shall keep written records of its proceedings,
which records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-204 Board of Local Improvements. There is hereby created a Board of Local
Improvements as provided by Statute.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, fact-finding body which shall make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to the construction,
extension, improvement or repair of any local improvements.
b. Members. The Board of Local Improvements shall consist of five members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees. Such members may be persons holding other Village government positions, but
no person holding a Village government position must be appointed.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Board of Local Improvements shall serve terms of five years or
until their successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. Terms of appointment
shall be staggered. Not more than one member shall be appointed in any one year unless
required by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually, the
Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one
of the members of the Board of Local Improvements to be president. No person shall serve
as chair more than three consecutive years unless the Village President determines that
continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village. The Board shall elect a
secretary from among its members.
Ord. #19-034)
d. Compensation. Members of the Board of Local Improvements shall serve without
compensation. Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel
Regulations.

1. The Board of Local Improvements shall adopt its own rules of procedure not in

2. The Board of Local Improvements shall have the powers and duties imposed by 65
ILCS 5/9-2-1 et seq.
Ord. #06-071)

Board of Local Improvements, or a quorum of the Board of Local Improvements. Three
members shall constitute a quorum. The president shall vote with other members of the
Board of Local Improvements.

proceedings, which records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-205 Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. There is hereby created a Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners as provided by Statute.
a. Intent and Purpose. To comply with the Statutes pertaining to the appointment of firefighters
and police officers.
b. Members. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall consist of three members,
residents of the Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall serve terms of
three years or until their successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. Terms of
appointment shall be staggered. Not more than one of the members shall be appointed in any
one year unless required by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms.
Annually, the Commissioners shall designate one of the members of the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three
consecutive years unless the Village President determines that continued service as chair is in
the best interests of the Village. The Village Manager shall designate a Village employee to
act as the secretary.
Ord. #19-034)
d. Compensation. Members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall serve without
compensation. Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel
Regulations.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-14 REVISED 10/07/19
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall
have such powers, duties and responsibilities assigned by the Board of Trustees, including
the following:
1. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall make rules for, and appointments
to, the Fire and Police Departments as is necessary, except as provided in paragraph 2
below and as that power may otherwise be reserved to the President and Board of
Trustees.
Ord. #19-034)
2. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint all officers and members
of the Fire and Police Departments of the Village, except the ranks above Police
Sergeant and Fire Lieutenant. All appointments made by the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners shall be from the rank next below that to which the
appointment shall be made, other than that of the lowest rank.
3. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall also make rules to provide for the
imposition of discipline upon members of the Fire and Police Departments,
including, but not limited to, suspension, demotion, reduction in rank and discharge.
Disciplinary action shall be in accordance with the statutes of the State of Illinois,
except as modified by the ordinances of the Village.
Ord. #13-034)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners shall be held at the call of the Chair. Special meetings may be called by the
Village President, the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners or a quorum of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. Two members
shall constitute a quorum. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Board.
Ord. #19-034)
g. Records and Reports. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall keep written
records of its proceedings, which records shall be open at all times to public inspection in
accordance with applicable law.

Section 6-207 Redevelopment Commission. There is hereby created a Redevelopment
Commission as permitted under the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-74.4-4, commonly known as the
Real Property Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act."
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for the appointment of a commission in the manner provided
by 65 ILCS 5/11-74.4-4 of the Real Property Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act
to exercise the powers granted under that statute to such commission.
b. Members. The Redevelopment Commission shall consist of nine members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Redevelopment Commission shall serve terms of five years or
until their successors are appointed and have qualified. Vacancies shall be filled only for
unexpired terms. Annually, the Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees, designate one of the members of the Redevelopment Commission to be
chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three consecutive years unless the Village
President determines that continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Redevelopment Commission shall serve without
compensation. Authorized travel expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village
travel regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Commission, subject to the approval of the
President and Board of Trustees, may exercise the powers enumerated under the provisions
of 65 ILCS 5/11-74.4-4, which is a section of the Real Property Tax Increment Allocation
Redevelopment Act. The Commission shall also have the power to hold the public hearings
required by 65 ILCS 5/11-74.4 and make recommendations to the President and Board of
Trustees concerning the adoption of redevelopment plans, redevelopment projects, and
designation of redevelopment project areas.
If any member of this Commission owns or controls an interest, direct or indirect, in any
property included in any redevelopment area, or proposed redevelopment area, he or she shall
disclose that in writing to the Village Clerk, and shall also disclose the dates and terms and
conditions of any disposition of any such interest, which disclosures shall be acknowledged
by the corporate authorities and entered upon the minute books of the corporate authorities.
If an individual holds such an interest, then that individual shall refrain from any further
official involvement in regard to such redevelopment plan, project or area, from voting on
any matter pertaining to such redevelopment plan, project or area, or communicating with
other members of the Commission, the corporate authorities or employees concerning any
matter pertaining to that redevelopment plan, project or area. Further, no such member shall
acquire any interest, direct or indirect, in any property in a redevelopment area or proposed
redevelopment area after either that individual obtains
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
17 REVISED 03/20/06
knowledge of such plan, project or area or the first public notice of such plan, project or area,
whichever occurs first.
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chair at such times
as may be required to fulfill the obligations imposed upon it under the terms of the Real
Property Tax Increment Allocation Redevelopment Act. Five members shall constitute a
quorum. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Commission.
g. Records and Reports. The Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings and
such other records as may be required by law. These records shall be open at all times to
public inspection.
Article III Boards of Trustees of Pension Funds Required by Statute
Section 6-301 Board of Trustees of the Firefighters Pension Fund. There is hereby created a
Board of Trustees of the Firefighters Pension Fund as provided under 40 ILCS 5/4-101 et seq.
a. Intent and Purpose. To comply with the statutes pertaining to control and management of the
Firefighters Pension Fund.
Ord. #06-010)
b. Board Created. The Board of Trustees of the Firefighters Pension Fund shall consist of the
following: two members of the Board shall be appointed by the Mayor or President of the
Board of Trustees of the municipality or the Fire Protection District involved. Twomembers
of the Board shall be active participants of the pension fund who are elected from the active
participants of the fund. One member of the Board shall be a person who is retired under the
Firemen’ s Pension Fund Act of 1919 or this Article 40 who is elected from persons retired
under the Firemen’ s Pension Fund Act of 1919 or this Article 40.
The terms of the Mayor’ s appointees shall be staggered with one appointee serving an initial
term of three years and one appointee serving an initial term of two years. After their initial
terms, each term shall be for three years or until a successor has been appointed.
The Board of Trustees of the Firefighters Pension Fund shall elect a president and secretary
from its members.
c. Powers and Duties of Board. The Board shall have the powers and duties in Section 4-123 to
4-129 inclusive, in addition to the other powers and duties granted to it in this Article.
1. Section 4-123. To control and manage the pension fund, and all money donated,
paid, assessed, or provided by law for the relief or pensioning of disabled,
superannuated and retired firefighters, their surviving spouses, minor children and
dependent parents.
2. Section 4-124. To assess each firefighter beginning January 1, 1987, 8.25% of salary
including longevity attached to the rank held by the firefighter as established
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
18 REVISED 05/06/96
by the Village appropriation ordinance, but not including "overtime pay", "holiday
pay", " bonus pay", " merit pay", or any other cash benefit over and above the salary
established by the appropriation ordinance, which sum is to be deducted and withheld
from the pay or fees of each firefighter so assessed. The deductions, together with all
interest accrued or accruing thereon, shall be placed bythe Treasurer of the Village as
Ex Officio Treasurer of the Board, to the credit of the pension fund, subject to the
order of the Board.
3. Section 4-125. To hear and decide all applications for relief or pensions under this
Article and to order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits.
4. Section 4-126. To make all rules and regulations necessary for the discharge of its
duties.
5. Section 4-127. To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses of
the Board.
6. Section 4-128. To invest the money of the pension fund only in accordance with 40
ILCS 5/4. Bonds purchased hereunder shall be registered in the name of the Board
or held under custodial agreement at a bank. No bank or savings and loan association
shall receive investment funds as permitted hereunder, unless it has complied with
the requirements established pursuant to Section 6 of "An Act Relating to Certain
Investments of Public Funds by Public Agencies," approved July23, 1943, as now or
hereafter amended. The limitation set forth in Section 6 shall be applicable only at
the time of investment and shall not require the liquidation of any investment at any
time.
7. Section 4-129. To keep a record of all its meetings and proceedings.
d. Section 4-134: Report for Tax Levy. The Board shall make a report to the Village Board of
Trustees of the condition of the pension fund prior to the meeting of the Village Board of
Trustees held for appropriating and levying of taxes for the year for which the report is made.
e. Section 4-137: No Compensation to Board. Members of the Board shall not receive or have
any right to receive any money or moneys from a pension fund as salary for service
performed as a member of the Board.
f. Section 4-142: Applicability of Home Rule Powers. No home rule unit, as defined in the
1970 Illinois Constitution or any amendment thereto, shall have the power to change, alter, or
amend in any way the provisions contained in 40 ILCS 5/4, and no home rule unit which is a
municipality, as defined in Section 4-103, shall provide for, singly or as a part of any plan or
program, by any means whatsoever, any type of retirement or annuity benefit to a firefighter
other than through establishment of a fund as provided in this Article as now or hereafter
amended.

Section 6-302 Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund. There is hereby created a Board of
Trustees of the Police Pension Fund as provided under 40 ILCS 5/3 et seq.
a. Intent and Purpose. To comply with the statutes pertaining to control and management of the
Police Pension Fund.
b. Board Created. The Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund shall consist of five
members comprised of the following: two members, who shall be appointed by the Village;
two members elected from among the regular police force, by the active members thereof;
and one member elected by and from the beneficiaries of the fund. The election of the
elected members of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund shall be held
biannually on the third Monday in April, at such place or places in the Village and under the
Australian ballot system and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed
members of the Board of Trustees of Police Pension Fund. The Board shall annually elect a
president and secretary from its members.
1. All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote for the police force
members.
2. All beneficiaries of legal age shall be entitled to vote for the member chosen from
among the beneficiaries.
3. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at any election.
c. Powers and Duties of Board. The Board shall have the powers and duties in Section 3-132 to
3-140, inclusive, of the State Statute, in addition to the other powers and duties granted to it
in this Article.
1. Section 3-132. To control and manage, exclusively, the pension fund, and all monies
donated, paid or assessed for the relief or pensioning of disabled, super-annuated and
retired members of the police department, their surviving spouses, minor children
and dependent parents. All such monies shall be placed by the Treasurer of the
Village to the credit of the fund, subject to the order of the Board.
2. Section 3-133. To order and direct the payment of pensions and other benefits
provided by this Article and to issue certificates signed by its President and Secretary
to the persons entitled thereto of the amount ordered paid to such persons from the
fund, which certificates shall state the purpose of the payment.
3. Section 3-134. To submit annually to the Village Board of Trustees at the close of
the Village's fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to payments from the fund, stating
the amount of the payments, and their purpose, as ordered by the Board. It shall also
include items of income accrued to the fund during that fiscal year. The list shall be
signed by the Secretary and President of the Board, and attested under oath. No
resolution or order for the payment of money shall be valid unless
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
20
approved by a majority of the members of the Board and any order for such payment
shall be signed by the President and Secretary of the Board.
4. Section 3-135. To invest the money of the pension fund only in accordance with 40
ILCS 5/3. Bonds purchased hereunder shall be registered in the name of the Board or
held under custodial agreement at a bank. No bank or savings and loan association
shall receive investment funds as permitted hereunder, unless it has complied with
the requirements established pursuant to Section 6 of "An Act Relating to Certain
Investments of Public Funds by Public Agencies," approved July23, 1943, as now or
hereafter amended. The limitation set forth in Section 6 shall be applicable only at
the time of investment and shall not require the liquidation of any investment at any
time.
5. Section 3-136. To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it, upon all matters
connected with the administration of this Article, in the manner provided by law for
the taking of testimony before the Circuit Court. The President, or anymember of the
Board, may administer oaths to such witnesses. To compel witnesses to attend and
testify before it, upon all matters connected with the administration of this Article, in
the manner provided by law for the taking of testimony before the Circuit Court. The
President, or any member of the Board, may administer oaths to such witnesses.
6. Section 3-137. To appoint a clerk and define the clerk's duties. No person drawing a
pension under this Article shall be employed by the Board.
7. Section 3-138. To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses,
including clerk hire, printing and witness fees.
8. Section 3-139. To keep a record of all its meetings and proceedings.
9. Section 3-140. To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the
provisions of this Article, which shall be published by the Board and copies
transmitted from time to time to all pensioners and contributors.
10. Section 3-141. On the 2nd Tuesday in May annually, the Treasurer and all other
officials of the Village, who had the custody of any pension funds herein provided,
shall make a sworn statement to the Board of the Police Pension Fund, and to the
President and Board Trustees of the Village, of all monies received and paid out by
them on account of the pension fund during the year, and of the amount of such funds
then on hand and owing to the pension fund. All surplus then remaining with any
official other than the Treasurer shall be paid to the Treasurer of the Village. Upon
demand of the Pension Board, any official shall furnish a statement relative to the
official method of collection or handling of such pension funds. All books and
records of such official shall be produced at any time for examination and inspection
by the Board.

21 REVISED 02/01/99
11. Section 3-142. Any police officer and any surviving spouse, child or children, or
dependent parent thereof, entitled to receive benefits under this Article, and to whom
the Board has ordered benefits to be paid, shall receive a yearly benefit payable in 12
equal monthly installments, which shall be the aggregate amount to which they are
entitled.
If at any time there are not sufficient monies in the fund to pay the allowances of the
Board to its beneficiaries, the Village Board of Trustees shall make every effort
consistent with law to replenish the fund so that all beneficiaries may receive the
amounts to which they are entitled. If, after every effort is made, there remains a
deficit in the fund, the beneficiaries shall be paid pro rata from the available funds,
but no allowance or order of the Board shall be held to create any liability against the
Village, except upon the fund so set apart as aforesaid for the payment thereof.
12. Section 3-143. The Board shall report to the Village Board of Trustees on the
condition of the police pension fund. The report shall be made prior to the meeting
of the Board of Trustees held for the levying of taxes for the year for which that
report is made. The Board shall certify to the Village Board of Trustees:
1st - The assets in their custody at such time;
2nd - The estimated receipts during the next succeeding calendar year from
deductions from the salaries of police officers, and from all other sources; and
3rd - The estimated amount required during the calendar year to pay all pensions and
other obligations provided in this Article, and to maintain the reserve fund provided
in Section 3-127.
13. Section 3-146. Members of the Board of Trustees of a pension fund shall not receive
or have any right to receive any money or monies from a pension fund as salary for
service performed as a member of such Board.
14. Section 3-150. No home rule unit, as defined in the 1970 Illinois Constitution or any
amendment, shall have the power to change, alter or amend in any way, the
provisions contained in this Article, and no such home rule unit which is a
municipality, as defined in Section 3-103, shall provide for, singly or as a part of any
plan or program, by any means whatsoever, any type of retirement or annuity benefit
to a policeman other than through establishment of a fund as provided in this Article
as now or hereafter amended.
Article IV Elected Board with Statutory Authority
Section 6-401 Board of Library Trustees. There is hereby created a Board of Library Trustees as
provided by Statute.
Ord. #99-005)
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an elective body of Trustees of the Arlington Heights
Memorial Library as provided in 75 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
22 REVISED 02/01/99
Ord. #99-005)
b. Members. The Board of Library Trustees shall consist of seven persons, residents of the
Village, elected as provided by Statute. In the event of a vacancy on the Board of Library
Trustees, the remaining trustees shall appoint a person to fill such vacancy until the next
scheduled library election.
c. Tenure. All members of the Board of Library Trustees shall serve terms of six years unless
appointed to fill a vacancy. The President of the Board of Library Trustees shall be
determined by the election of one of their number in the manner provided by Statute.
d. Compensation. Members of the Board of Library Trustees shall serve without compensation.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities.
1. The Board of Library Trustees shall have such powers, duties and responsibilities as
are provided by Statute.
2. The Board of Library Trustees shall have the power to make reasonable rules and
regulations governing the use of the Library and may exclude from the Library, any
person or persons who willfully violate such rules.
Ord. #99-005)
f. Meetings. Regular meetings of the Board of Library Trustees shall be held on the fourth
Tuesday of the month at 7:30 P.M.
g. Records and Reports.
1. The Board of Library Trustees shall keep written records of its proceedings, which
records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
2. The Board of Library Trustees shall make a written report of the financial condition
of the Library within 30 days after the termination of the fiscal year of the Village.
This report shall be filed with the Village Board of Trustees and shall be made in the
manner provided in 75 ILCS 5/1 et seq. Acopy of this report shall be filed with the
Illinois State Library at the same time, as is provided by statute. The Board of
Library Trustees shall also make such reports as may be requested from time to time
by the Village Board of Trustees.
h. Tax Levies and Bond Issues. An annual Library tax shall be levied by the Village Board of
Trustees and collected each year as provided by 75 ILCS 5/1 et seq. The issuance of Library
Bonds shall be in accordance with 75 ILCS 5/1 et seq.

Article V Other Boards and Commissions
Section 6-501 Design Commission. There is hereby created a Commission to be known as the
Design Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall, after due
deliberation, make recommendations to the Board of Trustees or the Building Commissioner
on matters relating to external architectural design, aesthetics, landscape and signs.
Ord. #09-020, #11-034)
b. Members. The Design Commission shall consist of five members, residents of the Village,
appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The membership of the Commission shall consist of a minimum of three
architects, one of whom may be a landscape architect, plus one member who is actually
engaged in business in Arlington Heights and one member who is an urban planner or a
person specifically qualified for reasons of education, training or experience in the area of
graphic or allied arts. Members with other experience and backgrounds maybe appointed in
the event members with the above background are unobtainable.
Ord. #01-033, #09-020)
c. Tenure. Except for original appointments, all members of the Design Commission shall
serve terms of three years or until their successors are appointed and have qualified.
Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Original appointments shall be two
members for terms of one year, two members for terms of two years and one member for a
term of three years. Annually, the Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees, designate one of the members of the Design Commission to be chair. No
person shall serve as chair more than three consecutive years, unless the Village President
determines that continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. The members of the Design Commission shall serve without compensation.
Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with the Village Travel Regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Design Commission shall have such powers,
duties and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, to
include those enumerated below:
1. Shall review all Plan Commission, Zoning Board of Appeals, Building Permit and
Sign Permit applications for new construction and those applications for
improvements which affect the architectural design of the building, site
improvements or signage to determine whether it meets with the standards,
requirements and purposes of the Design Guidelines and Chapter 30, Sign
Regulations.
2. Rules, Regulations and Procedures. The Design Commission shall prepare, adopt
and maintain such rules and regulations as are necessary to conduct the business of
the Design Commission and shall periodically review and update the Design
Guidelines.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-24 REVISED 10/07/19
3. The Commission may perform and exercise the following powers and duties:
a) To work toward the aesthetic growth and preservation of the community by
studying exterior design drawings, sign plans, landscape and site plans to
determine how the proposed development will relate to exterior architectural
design, arrangement, height and appearance, color and texture of the
materials of the exterior construction, landscaping, entrance ways, lighting,
off-street parking facilities and similar matters as set forth in the Design
Guidelines;
b) To review all applications for sign permits for signs in the Central Business
District and all requests for variations from Chapter 30;
c) To encourage and inspire public and private participation in the enhancement
of community appearance;
d) To hold public meetings, when required, for the issuance of Certificates of
Approval and to recommend issuance or denial of such certificates;
Ord. #09-020, #11-034)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Meetings of the Design Commission shall be held as needed,

the Board of Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the
Design Commission or a quorum of the Design Commission. Three members shall
constitute a quorum. The Chair shall vote with the other members of the Commission.
g. Records and Reports. The Design Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings,
which records shall be open to public inspection at all times.
Section 6-502 Building Code Review Board. There is hereby created a board to be known as the
Building Code Review Board.
Ord. #11-034)
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall, after due
deliberation, make recommendations to the Board of Trustees on matters relating to waivers
and amendments to the Building Code (Chapter 23) of the Village, as well as all adopted
International Code Council codes and administrative procedures relating to the enforcement
of the Building Code (Chapter 23) of the Village, as well as all adopted International Code
Council codes.
Ord. #19-034)
b. Members. The Building Code Review Board shall consist of six members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees. Members shall consist of the following: a Trustee of the Village who shall serve
during his or her term on the Village Board, a structural engineer, a building contractor, an
architect, a licensed electrician, and a mechanical engineer. Arepresentative of the Building
Department and a representative of the Fire Department shall each serve as Village
Administration Liaisons to the Board.

are appointed and have qualified. The terms of the contractor, structural engineer, architect
and mechanical engineer shall be staggered so that no more than two such members shall be
approved or reappointed in any one year, unless a vacancy exists. Vacancies shall be filled
only for unexpired terms. Annually, the Village President shall, with the advice and consent
of the Board of Trustees, designate one of the members of the Building Code Review Board
to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three consecutive years, unless the

regulations as are necessary to conduct its business;
2. The Building Code Review Board shall review all requests for amendments to the
Building Code of the Village;
3. The Building Code Review Board shall certify that materials submitted for review
shall meet performance standards as stipulated in the Building Code (Chapter 23) of
the Village, as well as all adopted International Code Council codes. Any materials
which have been certified by the Board as meeting performance standards may be
utilized for construction purposes under the terms of the Village Building Code;
4. The Building Code Review Board shall recommend to the Village Board that
variations be granted from the provisions of the Building Code (Chapter 23) of the
Village, as well as all adopted International Code Council codes, in cases where the
applicant for such variation demonstrates practical difficulty and particular hardship
in the strict application of the applicable Code, and the Board finds that the granting
of such variation will not endanger the public health, safety and welfare, and will
result in a standard of construction which is at least as strict as that required by the
existing Code. No variation may be granted without final action bythe President and
Board of Trustees;
5. The Building Code Review Board shall review the Building Code (Chapter 23) of the
Village, as well as all adopted International Code Council codes, from time to

procedures relating to the enforcement of the codes;
6. Any standards, specifications, rules, regulations and fees recommended bythe Board
shall not become effective until adopted by ordinance.

Section 6-504 Housing Commission. There is hereby created a commission to be known as the
Housing Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide an appointive, advisory body which shall:
1. Promote adequate housing for all the community's people, to create and/or maintain
sound viable neighborhoods, to meet the needs for housing by increasing the number
of housing units for low-and-moderate income families and individuals, and to
expand housing opportunities for all members of the community;
2. Constitute a Fair Housing Review Board, later referred to in this Section as the
Board, for the purpose of conducting hearings and acting in such a manner as set
forth in e. 3.
b. Members. The Housing Commission shall consist of seven members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Housing Commission shall serve terms of three years or until
their successors are appointed and have qualified. The terms of members shall be staggered
so that no more than three members shall be appointed or reappointed in any one year, unless
a vacancy exists. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms.
Annually the Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees,
designate one of the members of the Housing Commission to be Chair. No person shall
serve as chair more than three consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that
continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Housing Commission shall serve without compensation.
Authorized travel expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel
Regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Housing Commission shall have such powers,
duties and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, to
include those enumerated below:
1. Rules, Regulations and Procedures. The Housing Commission shall prepare, adopt
and maintain rules and regulations as are necessary to conduct the business of the
Commission.
2. The Commission may perform and exercise the following powers and duties:

a) To provide advice in the implementation of on-going affordable housing
programs;
b) To work with the surrounding communities and governmental agencies in
