3. Fair Housing Review Board.
a) The Fair Housing Review Board shall hear and investigate complaints
regarding discrimination in the sale, rental or financing of housing. It shall be
unlawful for any person, firm or corporation within the corporate limits of the
Village:
1) To refuse to sell or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to
refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make
unavailable or deny, dwelling to any person because of race, color,
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
30 REVISED 02/07/05
religion, national origin, familial status or disability, or because of
any other unlawful discrimination listed in Article 3 of the Illinois
Human Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or hereafter
amended;
2) To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions, or
privileges or sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of
services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color,
religion, national origin, familial status, disability or because of any
other unlawful discrimination listed in Article 3 of the Illinois Human
Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or hereafter amended;
3) To make, print, or publish or cause to be made, printed or published,
any notice, statement or advertisement, with respect to the sale or
rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or
discrimination based on a race, color, religion, national origin,
familial status or disability, or because of any other unlawful
discrimination listed in Article 3 of the Illinois Human Rights Act,
775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or hereafter amended, or an
intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination;
4) To represent to any person because of race, color, religion, national
origin, familial status, disability or because of any other unlawful
discrimination listed in Article 3 of the Illinois Human Rights Act,
775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or hereafter amended, that any
dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental, when a
dwelling is in fact available;
5) For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent
any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective
entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular
race, color, religion, national origin, familial status or disability, or
any other protected class listed in Article 3 of the Illinois Human
Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or hereafter amended;
6) For any bank, building and location association, firm or enterprise
whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of
commercial real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial
assistance to any person applying for the purpose of purchasing,
constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling, or to
discriminate against a person in the fixing of the amount, interest rate,
duration or other terms or conditions of the loan or other financial
assistance, because of the race, color, religion, national origin,
familial status or disability of that person or any person associated
with that person or any other protected class listed in Article 3 of the
Illinois Human Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or
hereafter amended, in connection with the loan or other financial
assistance or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
31 REVISED 02/07/05
occupants of the dwelling or dwellings in relation to which the loan
or other financial assistance is to be made or given.
b) Nothing in this Article shall prohibit a religious organization, association, or
society, or any non-profit institution or organization operated, supervised or
controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or
society, from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it
owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, to persons of religion,
from giving preference to such person, unless membership in the religion is
restricted on account of race, color, national origin, familial status or
disability or on account of any other unlawful discrimination listed in Article
3 of the Illinois Human Rights Act, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq., as now or
hereafter amended. The provisions of this Section shall not apply to rooms or
units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be
occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other, of
the owner actually maintains and occupies one of the living quarters as his or
her residence.
c) Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of Sections 6-
504(e)(3)(a)(1) to 6-504(e)(3)(a)(6) of the Code may, within 60 days after the
date of the alleged violation, file a written complaint with the Department of
Planning and Community Development setting forth the grievance to be
presented to the Board. The complaint shall state the name and address of the
complainant and of the persons against whom the complaint is brought and a
plain concise statement of the alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation.
d) The Board is fully authorized to immediately investigate each complaint
filed. However, the Board’s enforcement authority shall not be construed as a
limitation on the Village in seeking penalties or other remedial action from a
court of competent jurisdiction. The Board's investigation shall include an
opportunity for the complainant to be interviewed. If the Board determines
that the respondent has not committed a violation, it shall state its finding of
fact in writing and report it to the Board of Trustees. If the Board determines
that probable cause exists for the allegations made in the complaint, the
Board shall set a date for the conciliation hearing. At the hearing, the Board
shall interview the complainant and the person or persons against whom the
complaint has been directed, and attempt to resolve the complaint by all
proper methods of conciliation and persuasion. If such attempts at
conciliation are not successful within 60 days after the date of filing the
complaint, the Board shall then proceed promptly with full hearing.
e) The hearing shall be conducted by the Board or any four members thereof,
upon due and reasonable notice to all parties. The Board shall have full
power to subpoena witnesses and pertinent documents, which power may be
enforced by the Board by proper petition to any court of competent
jurisdiction. The Board shall have the power to administer oaths and to take
sworn testimony. Any person charged with a violation shall have the
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
32 REVISED 07/15/13
right to cross-examine witnesses. At the conclusion of the hearings, the
Board shall render a written report with findings and recommendations which
shall be served by mail upon the complainant and the respondent. No report
shall be delayed more than 60 days after the date of the issuance of notice for
commencement of the first hearing on the complaint.
f) Upon receipt of the report and recommendations, the President and Board of
Trustees shall thereupon set a date for consideration of the report with
recommendations at a public meeting. The President and Board of Trustees
shall give notice in writing at least five days prior to the date to all parties to
the hearings before the Review Board. At the public hearing, the President
and Board of Trustees may receive such further evidence or information as
they deem proper. If the President and Board of Trustees shall determine that
the respondent in such proceedings is guilty of a violation of any applicable
provision of Sections 6-504(e)(3)(a)(1) to 6-504(e)(3)(a)(6), itmaydirect that
appropriate legal action be taken against the respondent.
Ord. #13-037)
4. Affordable Housing Trust Fund
a) The Housing Commission shall make recommendations to the Village
Board regarding the following:
1) Goals for the use of Housing Trust Fund resources;
2) Annual Budget for the Housing Trust Fund;
3) Procedures for reviewing applications and awarding Housing Trust
Fund resources to applicants;
4) Criteria to be used in reviewing applications and programs that utilize
Housing Trust Fund resources;
5) Procedures to be used for disbursing Housing Trust Fund resources;
6) Review of applications and programs for Housing Trust Fund awards;
7) Procedures to be used to monitor Eligible Activities funded by the
Housing Trust Fund to ensure that Housing Trust fund resources are
used in conformance with all applicable requirements; and
8) Evaluation of Housing Trust Fund activities.
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Housing Commission shall be
scheduled at least monthly at a date and time to be determined by the Commission and
announced in the Village calendar and other appropriate media. Special meetings may be
called by the Village President, the Board of Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of
Trustees, the Chair of the Housing Commission or a quorum of the Commission. Four
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
6-33 REVISED 08/03/15
members shall constitute a quorum. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Commission.
g. Records and Reports.
1. The Housing Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which
records shall be open at all times to public inspection. An annual report shall be
made to the Committee-of-the-Whole, to include matters before the Commission and
their status.
2. When sitting as the Fair Housing Review Board, a copy of the report of each hearing
and recommendation pertaining thereto shall be submitted to the Village President
and Board of Trustees.
h. Any project or recommendation of the Housing Commission shall follow established
procedures of review through the Plan Commission, the Zoning Board of Appeals, and the
Village Board of Trustees as required by the Municipal Code. The powers and duties herein
granted to the Housing Commission shall be subject to approval and review by the Village
Board. The Village Manager is directed to render such advice and assistance to the Housing
Commission, including the provision of office space and personnel, as may be required to
effectuate the program of the Housing Commission. The Village Attorney shall act as
counsel to the Commission.

Section 6-505 The Arlington Economic Alliance. There is hereby created the Arlington Economic
Alliance.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body whose purpose shall be to
promote existing businesses and attract new businesses to the Village and to develop and
support programs in order to foster and support a Village-wide initiative towards the
promotion of quality economic development.
Ord. #02-025)
b. Members. The Arlington Economic Alliance shall consist of 13 members, either residents of
the Village or individuals working for a business located in the Village, appointed by the
Village President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. There shall
also be one member of the Village staff, appointed by the Village Manager, serving as
liaison.
Ord. #02-025, #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Arlington Economic Alliance, shall serve terms of three years or
until their successors are appointed and have qualified. The terms of members shall be
staggered so that no more than five members shall be appointed or reappointed in any one
year, unless a vacancy exists. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually,
the Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate
one of the members of the Arlington Economic Alliance to be chair. No person shall serve
as chair more than three consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that
continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
6-34 REVISED 08/03/15

cannot be filled from the designated category, the appointee maybe from any business within

powers, duties and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of
Trustees, to include those enumerated below:
1. The Arlington Economic Alliance shall prepare, adopt and maintain such rules and
regulations as are necessary to conduct the business of the Arlington Economic
Alliance.
2. The Arlington Economic Alliance shall promote economic development byactivities
including, but not limited to, the following:
a) Advising the Village on the development and implementation of business
retention/expansion programs;
b) Advising the Village on the implementation of a marketing program to attract
new business and industry;

levels;

d) Establishing a focal point for businesses to approach and discuss issues that

shall be made to the Board of Trustees, to include matters before the Arlington Economic
Alliance and their status.
Section 6-506 Senior Citizens' Commission. There is hereby created a commission to be known
as the Senior Citizens' Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall promote the
needs and concerns of the senior citizens of the Village of Arlington Heights and to
cooperate with the Village Government and all other governmental agencies in the promotion
of the cause of the senior citizen.
b. Members. The Senior Citizens' Commission shall consist of ten members, residents of the
Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Senior Citizen's Commission shall serve terms of three years or
until their successors are appointed and have qualified. The terms of members shall be
staggered so that no more than three members shall be appointed or reappointed in any one
year, unless a vacancy exists. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually,
the Village President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate
one of the members of the Senior Citizens' Commission to be chair. No person shall serve as
chair more than three consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that
continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.

6-36 REVISED 08/03/15
d. Compensation. Members of the Senior Citizens' Commission shall serve without compensation.

e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Senior Citizens' Commission shall have such
powers, duties and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of
Trustees, to include those enumerated below.
1. The Senior Citizens' Commission shall prepare, adopt and maintain such rules and
regulations as are necessary to conduct the business of the Commission.
2. Make recommendations from time to time to the Board of Trustees with respect to
adoption and amendment of ordinances relating to senior citizens.
3. Investigate the needs and concerns of the senior citizens, including housing,
employment, education, physical and mental health, income, nutrition, legal aid,

all other related areas of planning.
4. Analyze complaints of senior citizens of the Village of Arlington Heights.
5. Consult and cooperate with all agencies of the Village, other municipalities, and
federal, state and local agencies concerned with senior citizens.
6. Promulgate and effect a program of publicity relating to senior citizens and public
education relating to senior citizens.
7. Develop action programs of benefit to senior citizens and exercise such other
functions as may be delegated by the President and Board of Trustees.
8. Conduct public hearings, carry on research, or otherwise obtain such factual data and
issue such reports and recommendations to the Village Board and to the public as in
the judgment of the Commission will effectuate the policies and purpose of the
Commission.
9. The Commission shall annually, not later than the beginning of the fiscal year, submit
to the Village Board for approval a statement of its goals and objectives and
procedures for accomplishing them.

Section 6-507 Youth Commission. There is hereby created a commission to be known as the
Arlington Heights Youth Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall, after due
deliberation, make recommendations to the Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to the
welfare of the youth of the Village of all ages, particularly those in middle school and high
school. When authorized by the Board of Trustees, the Commission will take additional
steps and measures to promote youth programs.
Ord. #01-033, #07-041)
b. Members. The Commission shall consist of 13 members, six to be adult members and seven
to be youth members, high school students, appointed by the Village President by and with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, subject to the following conditions:
Appointments shall include at least one member from the staff of School District 214 or 25, a
representative of the Arlington Heights Park District, and a representative of the Arlington
Heights Police Department. The appointment of high school students shall be from among
the residents of the Village of Arlington Heights who are students of any high school serving
Arlington Heights residents. The adult members shall be residents of the Village or
employed within the Village in a professional capacity relating to youth work.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Commission, except high school students, shall serve terms of
three years or until their successors are appointed and have taken the oath of office. High
school students shall serve one year. Terms of appointment shall be staggered. Not more
than three members with three year terms shall be appointed in any one year unless required
by vacancies. Vacancies shall be filled only for unexpired terms. Annually, the Village
President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one of the
members of the Commission to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three
consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that continued service as chair is
in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation. Authorized
travel expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village travel regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Commission shall have such powers, duties and
responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, to include
those enumerated below:
1. The Commission shall prepare a statement of goals and objectives which shall be
reviewed and revised at least annually and submitted to the Village Board for
approval not later than the beginning of the fiscal year. Procedures for accomplishing
goals and objectives shall be included;
2. The Commission shall prepare, adopt and maintain such rules and regulations as are
necessary to conduct the business of the Commission;
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
38 REVISED 06/07/10
3. The Commission shall consider all existing youth programs sponsored bythe Village,
Township, County, State and Federal governments and by schools, parks, religious
institutions, and non-profit organizations. Those programs of value to the youth of
Arlington Heights will be brought to the attention of the Board of Trustees together
with recommendations to promote their use. When authorized or directed by the
Board of Trustees, promotional programs will be implemented;
4. Deficiencies in existing youth programs will be brought to the attention of the Board
of Trustees, together with recommendations for corrective action, to include the role
envisioned for the Village, Township, County, State and Federal governments;
religious institutions and private enterprise;
5. The Commission shall review the Village Administration's evaluations of youth
programs funded by the Village and recommend appropriate action to the Board of
Trustees;
6. The Commission shall recommend to the Board of Trustees, as part of the annual
budget process, appropriate budgets to support existing, new or modified youth
programs supported by evaluations and justifications.
Ord. #10-026)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. Regular meetings of the Commission shall be scheduled at least
monthly at a date and time to be determined by the Commission and announced in the
Village calendar and other appropriate media. Special meetings maybe called bythe Village
President, the Board of Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair
of the Commission or a quorum of the Commission. Seven members shall constitute a
quorum. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Commission.
g. Records and Reports. The Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which
records shall be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-508 Commission for Citizens with Disabilities. There is hereby created a commission
to be known as the Arlington Heights Commission for Citizens with Disabilities.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall promote the
needs and concerns of the citizens with disabilities of the Village of Arlington Heights and to
cooperate with the Village government and all other governmental agencies in the promotion
of the cause of people with disabilities.

residents of the Village, appointed by the Village President by and with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. Four members shall be persons with disabilities, that is,
persons who have a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more
major life activities.
Ord. #09-020)

three years or until their successors are appointed and have qualified. The terms of members

more than three consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that continued
service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.

without compensation. Authorized travel expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with

development of comprehensive plans for bikeways and pedestrian travel within the Village of
Arlington Heights and cooperate with the Village and other governmental agencies in the

b. Members. The Commission shall consist of seven members, residents of the Village,
appointed by the Village President by and with the consent and advice of the Board of

Ord. #09-020)

Advisory Commission shall serve terms of three years or until their successors are appointed
and have qualified. Original appointments shall be two members for terms of one year, two
members for terms of two years and three members for terms of three years. Vacancies shall
be filled in the manner set forth in paragraph b. above. Annually, the Village President
shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one of the members of
the Commission to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three consecutive
years, unless the Village President determines that continued service as chair is in the best
interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Commission shall serve without compensation. Authorized
expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village regulations.

those enumerated below:
1. Prepare, adopt and maintain such rules and regulations as are necessary to conduct
the business of the Commission;
2. Prepare a statement of goals and objectives, and procedures for accomplishing them,
which shall be submitted to the Village Board for approval not later than the
beginning of each fiscal year;

41 REVISED 09/21/09
3. Recommend a comprehensive bikeways system plan for the Village of Arlington
Heights;
4. Recommend a comprehensive bicycle education and safety program.
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. The Commission shall adopt a schedule of meetings to be
announced in the Village calendar and other appropriate media. Special meetings may be
called by the Village President, the Board of Trustees, the Liaison Committee of the Board of
Trustees, the Chair of the Commission or a quorum of the Commission. Four members of
the Commission shall constitute a quorum to carry on the business of the Commission. The
Chair shall vote with other members of the Commission.

be open at all times to public inspection.
Section 6-510 Special Events Commission. There is hereby created a commission to be known as
the Arlington Heights Special Events Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive advisory body which shall promote,
organize and implement special events of civic, patriotic, educational and cultural nature in
the Village of Arlington Heights.
Ord. #03-024)
b. Members. The Commission shall consist of twelve members, appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. The holding of any
other appointed or elected position in the Village of Arlington Heights shall not disqualify an
appointee to the Commission.
Ord. #09-020)
c. Tenure. All members of the Commission shall serve for a period of four years; provided,
however, that the original terms shall be staggered so that five members originally appointed
shall serve two years and six members shall serve for four years, and that thereafter all
appointments shall be for four years. All vacancies as mayoccur on the Commission shall be
filled in the manner hereinabove set forth for original appointments. Annually, the Village
President shall, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, designate one of the
members of the Commission to be chair. No person shall serve as chair more than three
consecutive years, unless the Village President determines that continued service as chair is
in the best interests of the Village.
d. Compensation. Members of the Special Events Commission shall serve without
compensation. Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village
regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Commission shall have such powers, duties and
responsibilities by the Board of Trustees, including the following:
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
42 REVISED 09/21/09
1. To investigate opportunities for special events of civic, patriotic, educational and
cultural nature, such as will promote the best interests of the Village of Arlington
Heights;
2. To make recommendations to the Board of Trustees from time to time with respect to
such special events;
3. To study special events in other communities and localities for possible adoption and
promotion in the Village of Arlington Heights;
4. To develop programs to promote such special events as may be established, both by
the Village of Arlington Heights and by other community, civic or patriotic
organizations when such promotion is in the best interests of the Village of Arlington
Heights; and
5. To submit an annual report with recommendations to the Village Board indicating the
plans and programs of the Commission.
Ord. #03-024)
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. On its organization, the Commission shall adopt a schedule of
meetings to be announced in the Village calendar or other appropriate media. Special

Committee of the Board of Trustees, the Chair of the Commission or a quorum of the

business of the Commission. The Chair shall vote with other members of the Commission.

Section 6-512 Arts Commission. There is hereby created a Commission to be known as the Arts
Commission.
a. Intent and Purpose. To provide for an appointive, advisory body which shall, after due
deliberation, make recommendations to the President and Board of Trustees on the
acquisition of public art within the Village of Arlington Heights.
Ord. #01-001, #09-020)
b. Members. The Arts Commission shall consist of nine members, residents of the Village,
appointed by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees.
Annually, the Village President shall designate one of the persons so appointed as chair. No
person shall serve as chair more than three consecutive years unless the Village President
determines that continued service as chair is in the best interests of the Village.
c. Tenure. Except for original appointments, all members of the Arts Commission shall serve
terms of three years, or until their successors are appointed and have qualified. The terms of
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
43 REVISED 09/21/09
members shall be staggered so that no more than three members shall be appointed or
reappointed in any one year, unless a vacancy exists. Vacancies shall be filled only for
unexpired terms.
d. Compensation. The members of the Arts Commission shall serve without compensation.
Authorized expenses shall be reimbursed in accordance with Village Travel Regulations.
e. Powers, Duties and Responsibilities. The Arts Commission shall have such powers, duties
and responsibilities as are assigned by the Village President and Board of Trustees, to include
those enumerated below:
1. Prepare, adopt and maintain such rules and regulations as are necessary to
conduct the business of the Commission;
2. Invite, enlist and encourage the cooperation of public and private agencies and
the general public in support of cultural advancement within the Village;
3. Facilitate greater awareness of the arts;
4. Make recommendations to the Village Board for the provisions of an
environment in which the cultural arts will flourish within the Village.
f. Meetings, Quorum, Voting. The Commission shall adopt a schedule of meetings to be
announced in the Village calendar and other appropriate media. The Commission shall meet

by the Village President, the Board of Trustees or a quorum of the Arts Commission. Five
members shall constitute a quorum.
g. Records and Reports. The Arts Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings,
which records shall be open to public inspection at all times.

Article I Personnel
Section 7-101 Scope. The provisions of this Article shall apply equally to all officers and
employees of the Village, regardless of the time of the creation of the office or position or the time of
the election or appointment of the officer or employee unless another provision of this Code
specifically provides for some other treatment.
Section 7-102 Appointment. Appointments shall be made by the person, and in the manner,
provided by the provisions of this Code. If the provisions of this Code do not indicate who shall
appoint, or in what manner the appointment shall be made, the following rules shall apply.
a. Administrative Appointments. The Village Manager shall make all appointments of officers
or employees whose work shall be concerned with the administration of the Village.
b. Other Appointments. All other appointments of persons who shall advise the Board of
Trustees on Village policy shall be made by the President with the advice and consent of the
Board of Trustees.
Section 7-103 Term of Office. Every elected officer shall hold office for the term prescribed bythe
provisions of this Code or by statute. Every appointed officer or employee shall hold office for the
term specified in the provisions of this Code; if no term is specified, then, he shall hold office for an
indefinite term and may be removed at the discretion of the appointing officer.
Section 7-104 Vacancies. Vacancies in elected offices shall be filled as provided by the provisions
of this Code or by statute. Vacancies in appointed offices shall be filled in the same manner as such
appointments were first made; provided, however, that where an officer is appointed for a specified
term, the appointment to fill the vacancy shall only be for the remainder of that term.
Section 7-105 Oath. Every officer of the Village, before entering upon the duties of office, shall
take an oath in the manner and form prescribed by the provisions of this Code or by Statute.
Section 7-106 Compensation. All officers and employees of the Village shall receive such
compensation as the President and Board of Trustees shall, from time to time, provide byordinance.
Section 7-107 Bond. Every officer or employee shall, if required by the provisions of this Code, by
Statute or by the Board of Trustees, before beginning the duties of office, give a bond in such
amount and with such sureties as may be determined by the source requiring such bond, conditioned
upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office or position.
Section 7-108 Termination of Office. Every officer and employee of the Village, upon the
expiration of his or her term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his her successor all books
and records which are the property of the Village, and if no successor has been appointed within
one week after the termination of the term of office, all such Village property shall be turned over to
the officer who appointed or hired such officer or employee, or, in the case of an elected officer, such
property shall be turned over to the Village Clerk.
OTHER VILLAGE GOVERNMENT PROVISIONS
7-6
Section 7-109 Qualifications for Officeholders. No person except as provided below shall be
eligible to hold any office in the Village government who is not a qualified elector of the Village, and
who has not resided within the Village for at least one year next preceding his or her election or
appointment. No person who has defaulted on any obligation to the Village or who is presently in
default shall be eligible for election or appointment.
Article II Records
Section 7-201 Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words or terms,
whenever used in this Chapter, shall have the following meanings:
a. Employee. All persons appointed by the Village Manager in either permanent or temporary
capacities, including those working both full-time and part-time.
b. Local Records Commission. The Cook County Local Records Commission as provided by
Statute.
c. Officer. All elected persons, all appointed members of Boards and Commissions, the Village
Manager, the Village Attorney and the Village Prosecutor.
d. Public Agency. All boards, commissions, departments, divisions or any part of the Village
government of Arlington Heights.
e. Public Record. Any book, paper, map, photograph, or other official documentary material,
regardless of physical form or characteristics, made, produced, executed or received by any
public agency or officer pursuant to law or in connection with the transaction of public
business and preserved or appropriate for preservation by such agency or officer, or any
successor thereof, as evidence of the organization, function, policies, decisions, procedures,
or other activities thereof, or because of the informational data contained therein. Library
and museum material made or acquired and preserved solely for reference or exhibition
purposes, extra copies of documents preserved only for convenience of reference, and stocks
of publications and of processed documents are not included within the definition of public
record.
Section 7-202 Original Records: Destruction. All public records made or received by, or under
the authority of, or coming into the custody, control or possession of any officer or public agency
shall not be mutilated, destroyed, transferred, removed or otherwise damaged or disposed of, in
whole or in part, except as provided by the provisions of this Code and by Statute.
Section 7-203 Destruction of Public Records. Except as otherwise provided by Statute, no public
record shall be disposed of by any officer or public agency unless the written approval of the Local
Records Commission is first obtained.
Section 7-204 Regulations. The Local Records Commission regulations pertaining to the
destruction, or microfilming and destruction of records shall be binding on all officers and public
agencies as provided by Statute.
Section 7-205 Records Not Public Records. Non-record materials or materials not included within
the definition of public records, may be destroyed at any time by the officer or agency in possession
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
7-7 REVISED 10/15/18
of such materials without the prior approval of the Local Records Commission. The Local Records
Commission has the power, by Statute, to formulate advisory procedures and interpretation to guide
in the disposition of materials which are not public records.
Section 7-206 Certificate of Intent. Prior to the destruction of any of the original records, as
permitted by Statute, the officer of the public agency having such public records in custody or under
his or her supervision shall attach to each reproduction or continuous roll of reproductions, as the
case may be, a certification as provided by Statute.

Article III Emergency Management Agency
Section 7-301 Establishment. There is hereby created the Village of Arlington Heights Emergency
Management Agency (“ EMA”), established to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile actions or from
natural or man-made disasters, in accordance with "The Illinois Emergency Management Agency
Act" (“ Act”), as now or hereafter amended. The EMA shall consist of the Village Manager, who
shall serve as EMA Director, the Coordinator, who shall be designated by the Director, and such
other members as selected by the EMA Director. The Coordinator shall be under the authority,
command, and control of the EMA Director.
Section 7-302 Director. Under the supervision of the Village President, the EMA Director shall
have the responsibility for the management of the EMA. In the event of the absence, resignation,
death, or inability of the Village Manager to serve as the EMA Director, the Village President, or
individual designated by the Village President, shall act as EMA Director until a new Village
Manager is appointed or other individual is appointed EMA Director.
Section 7-303 Coordinator. Under the supervision of theEMADirector, the Coordinator shall have
direct responsibility for the planning, coordination, and operation of the emergency management
activity in the Village. The Coordinator shall serve as liaison with the State and Federal authorities
and the authorities of other nearby political subdivisions to ensure the most effective operation of the
Emergency Operations Plan. The Coordinator's duties shall include, but not be limited to, the
following:
a. Coordinating the recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel
and facilities of the Village for emergency management purposes.
b. Development and coordination of plans for the immediate use of all Village facilities,
equipment, manpower and other resources for the purposes of minimizing or preventing
damage to persons and property and protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental
services and public utilities necessary for the public health, safety and welfare.
c. Negotiating and concluding agreements with owners or persons in control of buildings or
other property for the use of such buildings or other property for emergency management
purposes, and designating suitable buildings as public shelters.
d. Conducting public practice alerts to ensure the efficient operation of emergency management
regulations, procedures, and operations.
OTHER VILLAGE GOVERNMENT PROVISIONS
7-8 REVISED 10/15/18
e. Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any emergency
management activity.
f. Assuming such authority and conducting such activity as the EMA Director may direct to
promote and execute the Emergency Operations Plan.
g. In the event of the absence, resignation, death, or inability to serve of the Coordinator, the
EMA Director or another person designated by the EMA Director, shall act as Coordinator
until a new appointment is made.
Section 7-304 Membership with the Joint Emergency Management System. The Village is a
member of the Joint Emergency Management System (“ JEMS”), a regional system among
neighboring municipalities for emergency management support. As a member of JEMS, the Village
coordinates its emergency management program activities with the JEMS Coordinator in order to
ensure regional standardization.
Section 7-305 Functions. The VillageEMAshall perform suchEMAfunctions within the Village as
shall be prescribed in and by the State of Illinois EMA plan and program prepared by the Governor,
and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as maybe required pursuant to
any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipality
entered into as provided in the Act.
Section 7-306 Emergency Plans.
a. Acomprehensive Emergency Operations Plan shall be adopted and maintained byresolution
of the Corporate Authorities upon the recommendations of the Village President. In the
preparation of the Plan as it pertains to the Village organization, it is the intent that the
services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be
utilized to the fullest extent. When approved, it shall be the duty of the EMA Director, all
departments, and all employees to perform the functions assigned bythe Plan and to maintain
their portion of the Plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The Emergency
Operations Plan shall be considered supplementary to this Chapter and have the effect of law
whenever a disaster has been proclaimed.
b. Each department head assigned responsibility in the Emergency Operations Plan shall be
responsible for carrying out all duties and functions assigned therein. Duties will include the
organization and training of assigned Village employees and volunteers.
c. The Village President shall prescribe in a Continuity of Operations and Continuity of
Government Plan those positions within the disaster organization, in addition to their own,
for which lines of succession are necessary. In each instance, the responsible person will
designate and keep on file with the Village a current list of three persons as successors to the
position. The list will be in order of succession and will as nearly as possible designate
persons best capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions.
d. When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the
Village government, the Village President is authorized to seek assistance from persons
outside of government. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall also
grant authority for the persons so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during, and after
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
7-9 REVISED 10/15/18
a disaster. The Village may accept such services from persons outside of government on a
volunteer basis. Such persons shall be enrolled as emergency management volunteers in
cooperation with the heads of departments affected.
e. Some of the duties ascribed to the Village President in this Article will ordinarily be handled
as a matter of routine by the EMA Director or Coordinator, but the responsibility and
authority stem from and remain with the Village President.
Section 7-307 Service as Mobile Support Team. Any member of the Village EMA may be
designated as a member of a mobile support team created by the Director of the State of Illinois
Emergency Management Agency as provided by law. The leader of the mobile support team shall be
designated by theEMA Director. Any member of a mobile support team who is a Village employee
or officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor or the State Director shall receive the
compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or
office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the Village while so serving shall
receive reasonable compensation from the State of Illinois as provided by law.
Section 7-308 Emergency Action. If the Governor proclaims that a disaster or state of emergency
exists n the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the State of
Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action or from man-made
or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the VillageEMAto cooperate fully with the State of Illinois
EMA and with the Governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law.
Section 7-309 Reimbursement by State. The Treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate
fund any reimbursement by the State of Illinois to the Village for expenses incident to training
members of the EMA as prescribed by the State Director of EMA, compensation for services and
expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the Village in response to a call
by the Governor or State Director ofEMAas provided bylaw, and any other reimbursement made by
the State incident to EMA activities as provided by law.
Section 7-310 Purchases and Expenditures. The Board of Trustees, may, on recommendation of
the Village Director of EMA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the Village in a
position to combat effectively any enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the
State of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from
man-made or natural disasters and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and
provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster.
In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the Village Director ofEMA is authorized, on behalf
of the Village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as maybe necessary for such
purposes, in view of the emergency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities
normally prescribed by law pertaining to Village contracts or obligations, as authorized by "The
Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act", as amended; provided, that if the Village President is
available at such time, the Village Director shall act subject to the direction and restrictions imposed
by the Village President.
Section 7-311 Oath. Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Village EMA
organization shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the following oath:

Article IV Emergency Powers of the Village President
Section 7-401 Emergency Powers and Duties. During any period when disaster threatens or when
the Village has been struck by disaster, the Village President or theEMA Director may promulgate
such regulations as deemed necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources.
Such regulations may include, but shall not be limited to, the following:
a. Regulations prohibiting or restricting the movement of vehicles in order to facilitate the work
of emergency management personnel or to facilitate the mass movement of persons from
critical areas within or without the Village.
b. Regulations pertaining to the movement of persons from areas deemed to be hazardous or
vulnerable to disaster.
c. Such other regulations necessary to preserve public peace, health and safety.
Section 7-402 Governmental Powers. Whenever, due to an emergency resulting from the effects
of natural or manmade disaster or hostile act or the anticipated effects thereof, it becomes imprudent,
inexpedient or impossible to conduct the affairs of local government at the regular or usual place or
places, the Village Board may meet at any place within or outside the Village limits on the call of the
presiding officer or any two members of such governing body. The Village Board shall proceed to
establish and designate by ordinance, resolution, or other manner alternate or substitute sites or
places as the emergency temporary location or locations of government where all or any part of the
public business may be transacted and conducted during the emergency situation. Such sites or
places may be within or outside the Village.
During the period when the public business is being conducted at the emergency temporary location
or locations, the governing body and other officers of the Village shall have all of the executive,
legislative, and judicial powers and functions conferred upon such body and officers by the laws of
this State. Such powers and functions may be exercised in light of the exigencies of the emergency
situation without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
7-10b REVISED 10/15/18
prescribed by law and pertaining thereto, and all acts of such body and officers shall be valid and
binding as if performed within the Village.
Section 7-403 Continuity In Office. In the event that the Village President is unavailable, the
powers of the office shall be exercised and duties shall be discharged by the designated emergency
interim successors in the order specified. The emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers
and discharge the duties of the office to which designated until such time as a vacancy which may
exist shall be filled in accordance with the constitution or statutes; or until the officer, or their deputy
or a preceding emergency interim successor, again becomes available to exercise the powers and
discharge the duties of the office. Based on the authority of 5 ILCS 275/3 the line of succession for
the executive branch of government will be: Village President, President Pro Tem, Senior Trustee.
In the event that, at the time or as a consequence of any disaster or occurrence described in this
Chapter, the Village President and their successors on file with the Village shall be absent, killed, or
rendered incapable of performing the duties of such office, such office shall be filled until such time
as a successor can be selected in the manner prescribed by law, in the following line of succession:
the remaining members of the Village Board based on tenure, the Village Manager, the Director of
Finance, the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief, the Public Works Director. In the event that, at the time
or as a consequence of any disaster or occurrence described in this Chapter, the incumbent of any
Municipal office or position shall be absent, killed, or rendered incapable of performing the duties of
such office or position, such office or position shall be filled, until such time as a successor can be
selected in the manner prescribed by law, by appointment by the Village President. The Village
President shall give due consideration to the list of three successors on file with the Village but is not
required to select from said list.
Section 7-404 Local Disaster Emergencies. A local disaster emergency may be proclaimed only
by the Village President as provided by "The Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act", as
amended. The local disaster emergency shall be continued only as provided byStatute. It shall be the
duty of the Village EMA to cooperate fully with the Village President in the exercise of emergency
powers as provided by law during the time of a local disaster emergency.
Section 7-405 Power and Authority Granted. Upon declaring a Local Disaster Emergency, the
Village President may:
a. Order a general curfew applicable to the geographical areas of the Village, or to the Village
as a whole, as the Village President deems reasonably necessary to respond to the emergency,
and applicable during the hours of the day or night as the Village President deems necessary
in the interests of the public safety and welfare.
b. Prohibit the sale of any firearm of any size or description and the sale of any ammunition,
explosive or other destructive device.
c. Prohibit the intentional possession in public view of any firearm by any person except a duly
authorized law enforcement officer or military person active in the official performance of
his or her duty.
d. Order the establishment of curfews, including vehicle movement except fire, police, hospital
services, utility vehicles and physicians on emergency cases.
OTHER VILLAGE GOVERNMENT PROVISIONS
7-10c REVISED 10/15/18
e. Prohibit the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, with or without payment, or the
possession of any portable container containing any alcoholic beverage by any person in a
public place.
f. Order the closing of places of public assemblage.
g. Prohibit the sale or transfer or possession of gasoline or other combustible liquid except for
delivery directly into the tank of a motor vehicle, boat or other combustion-propelled vehicle.
h. Prohibit the possession in a public place of any portable container containing combustible
liquid.
i. Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property.
Section 7-406 Notification. Upon issuance of the executive order declaring a Local Disaster
Emergency, the appropriate public official shall notify the news media situated within the Village
and shall cause two copies of the executive order declaring the existence of the State of Emergency
to be posted at the Municipal Building and the Police Department.
Section 7-407 Duration. A declaration of a Local Disaster Emergency shall expire not later than
the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities after the Local Disaster
Emergency is declared, unless terminated earlier by proclamation of the Village President that the
Local Disaster Emergency no longer exists.
Article V Emergency Energy Plans
Ord. #99-033)
Section 7-501 Definitions. Whenever any of the following terms are used in this Article they
shall have the meaning indicated.
a. State of Emergency. State of Emergency shall mean an occurrence or threat of widespread or
severe damage, where extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health,
safety and welfare from injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or
technological cause, including but not limited to fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm,
hazardous materials spill or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert
danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, extended periods of severe and
inclement weather, drought, infestation, critical shortages of essential fuels and energy,
explosion, riot or hostile military or paramilitary action.
b. Curfew. Curfew shall mean a prohibition against any person or persons being present at or
upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway with the exception of officials
of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to a State
of Emergency duly declared by executive order pursuant to this Article.
Section 7-502 State of Emergency.
a. Whenever a State of Emergency, as defined in this Article exists, the Village Manager or his
or her designee shall report the circumstance to the Village President. The report shall
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
11 REVISED 05/17/99
include the nature of the emergency, the geographic area or areas involved, and the specific
remedies requested.
b. The Village President may declare a State of Emergency by written executive order
containing a statement signed by the Village President, under oath setting forth the following:
1. One or more of the conditions which have been met for the determination of a State
of Emergency;
2. Facts to substantiate such findings;
3. A description of the nature of the emergency; and
4. Declaration that a State of Emergency exists.
This statement must be filed with the Village Clerk as soon as practicable.
c. The Village President may exercise the extraordinary power and authority granted in this
Article when such a State of Emergency exists but not until after signing, under oath, the
executive order.
Section 7-503 Power and Authority Granted. Upon declaring a State of Emergency, the Village
President may:
a. Order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the Village or to the Village
as a whole, as the Village President deems reasonably necessary to respond to the
Emergency, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as the Village President
Deems necessary in the interests of the public safety and welfare;
b. Prohibit the sale of any firearm of any size or description and the sale of any ammunition,
explosive or other destructive device;
c. Prohibit the intentional possession in public view of any firearm by any person except a duly
authorized law enforcement officer or military person active in the official performance of
his duty.
d. Order the establishment of curfews, including vehicle movement except fire, police, hospital
services, utility vehicles and physicians on emergency cases;
e. Prohibit the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages, with or without payment, or the
possession of any portable container containing any alcoholic beverage by any person in a
public place;
f. Order the closing of places of public assemblage;

g. Prohibit the sale or transfer or possession of gasoline or other combustible liquid except for
delivery directly into the tank of a motor vehicle, boat or other combustion-propelled vehicle;
h. Prohibit the possession in a public place of any portable container containing combustible

i. Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property.
Section 7-504 Notification. Upon issuance of the executive order declaring a State of Emergency,
the appropriate public official shall notify the news media situated within the Village and shall cause
two copies of the executive order declaring the existence of the State of Emergency to be posted at
the Municipal Building and the Police Department.
Section 7-505 Duration. A declaration of a State of Emergency shall expire not later than the
adjournment of the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities after the State of Emergency is
declared, unless sooner terminated by proclamation of the Village President indicating that the State
of Emergency no longer exists.
Section 7-506 Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be fined
not less than five dollars nor more than five hundred dollars.

Article VII Budget Policy and Process
Ord. #99-033)
Section 7-701 Adoption of Budget Procedures. The Village of Arlington Heights adopts 65 ILCS
5/8-2-9.1 through 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.10, as now or hereafter amended, to establish the budget
procedures.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
13 REVISED 05/17/99
Section 7-702 Appointment of the Budget Officer. The Finance Director shall serve as the
Budget Officer.
Section 7-703 Passage of the Budget. The annual budget ordinance will be passed and adopted bya
majority vote of the corporate authorities then holding office, including the President of the Board,
before the beginning of the fiscal year for which it applies. Passage of the annual budget ordinance
shall be in lieu of an annual appropriation ordinance as required by 65 ILCS 5/ 8-2-9.
Section 7-704 Contents of the Budget.
a. There shall be a single budget document which identifies all expected revenues and
expenditures of Village-owned funds. The budget document shall contain all budgeted line
items.
b. The budget document shall contain estimates of the revenues available to the Village for the
fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended expenditures of all
Village operations. Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations will be presented
in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management practices. The budget shall
contain actual or estimated revenues and expenditures for at least two years immediately
preceding the fiscal year for which the budget is prepared.
c. Each budget shall show the specific fund from which each anticipated expenditure shall be
made.
Section 7-705 Budget Revisions.
a. The annual budget may be revised by deleting, adding to, changing or creating sub-classes
within object classes and object classes themselves or byincreasing the total appropriation of
a fund. All budget revisions require a 2/3 vote of the corporate authorities then holding
office, including the President, except for administrative transfers as provided for in
subsection b. below.
b. The Village Manager or designee may transfer budgeted expenditure amounts affecting any
category of expenditure by no more than $10,000 within and between departments within any
fund. Transfers made under the provisions of this subsection shall be reported to the Board
of Trustees on a monthly basis.
c. Budget revenue amounts may be changed bythe Village Manager, when deemed appropriate,
based on revised revenue estimates. Such changes shall be reported to the Board of Trustees
on a monthly basis.
d. In the case of an emergency, the Village Manager, President, or Board of Trustees may
declare that a state of emergency exists. Such declaration authorizes the Village Manager to
award contracts, acquire services, and make purchases for the purpose of meeting the public
emergency, notwithstanding whether there is an adequate budget or available funds for the
expenditure. The Manager, within 14 days, shall file a memorandum to the Board
OTHER VILLAGE GOVERNMENT PROVISIONS
14 REVISED 12/18/00
identifying the emergency and the necessity of emergency action together with an accounting
of all proposed expenditures.
e. No revision to the budget shall be made in the event funds are not available to effectuate the
purpose of the revision, except as provided in subsection d above.
Section 7-706 Contingencies. The annual budget may contain money set aside for contingency
purposes not to exceed ten percent of the total budget, less the amount set aside for contingency
purposes, which monies may be expended for contingencies upon a majority vote of the corporate
authorities then holding office or under the transfer provisions of this Article.
Section 7-707 Infrastructure/Capital Equipment Funding.
a. Monies may be accumulated for the purpose or purposes of current or future, specified and
unspecified, capital equipment and infrastructure improvements, repair or replacement.
b. Expenditures from monies accumulated for capital equipment and infrastructure
improvements, repair or replacement shall be budgeted in the fiscal year for which the capital
and infrastructure improvement, repair or replacement will occur.
Section 7-708 Public Inspection, Hearing, Notice and Publication.
a. The corporate authorities shall make the proposed annual budget conveniently available for
public inspection at least ten days prior to the public hearing on the budget, in such form as
the corporate authorities may prescribe. Copies shall be made available at the Arlington
Heights Municipal Building and at the Arlington Heights Public Library.
b. Notices of availability for public inspection of the budget and of the public budget hearing
shall be given at least ten days prior to the time of the hearing by publication in a newspaper
having general circulation in the municipality.
c. Not less than one week after the publication of the tentative annual budget and prior to final
action on the budget, the corporate authorities shall hold at least one public hearing on the
tentative annual budget, after which the budget may be further revised and passed without
further inspection, notice or hearing.
d. The annual budget shall be published in pamphlet form as provided by law.
Article VIII
Locally Imposed and Administered Tax Rights and Responsibility
Ord. #00-082)
Section 7-801 Scope. The provisions of this Article shall apply to the Village’s procedures in
connection with all of the Village’ s locally imposed and administered taxes.
Section 7-802 Definitions. Certain words or terms herein shall have the meaning ascribed to them
as follows:
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
15 REVISED 12/18/00
a. Act. The "Local Government Taxpayers’ Bill of Rights Act."
b. Corporate Authorities. The Village’s President and Board of Trustees.
c. Locally imposed and administered tax or tax. Each tax imposed by the Village that is
collected or administered by the Village not an agency or department of the State. It does not
include any taxes imposed upon real property under the Property Tax Code or fees collected
by the Village other than infrastructure maintenance fees.
d. Local tax administrator. The Village’ s Finance Director, is charged with the administration
and collection of the locally imposed and administered taxes, including staff, employees or
agents to the extent they are authorized by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax
administrator’ s stead. The local tax administrator shall have the authority to implement the
terms of this ordinance to give full effect to this ordinance. The exercise of such authority by
the local tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this ordinance and the Act.
e. Village. The Village of Arlington Heights, Illinois.
f. Notice. Each audit notice, collection notice or other similar notice or communication in
connection with each of the Village’ s locally imposed and administered taxes.
g. Tax Ordinance. Each ordinance adopted bythe Village that imposes any locally imposed and
administered tax.
h. Taxpayer. Any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and
generally includes the person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax is placed and with
respect to consumer taxes includes the business or entity required to collect and pay the
locally imposed and administered tax to the Village.
Section 7-803 Notices. Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the
notice is to be in writing mailed not less than seven calendar days prior to the day fixed for any
applicable hearing, audit or other scheduled act of the local tax administrator. The notice shall be
sent by the local tax administrator as follows: 1) first class or express mail, or overnight mail,
addressed to the persons concerned at the persons’ last known address, or 2) personal service or
delivery.
Section 7-804 Late payment. Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made
to the Village pursuant to any tax ordinance shall be considered late unless it is (a) physically
received by the Village on or before the due date, or (b) received in an envelope or other container
displaying a valid, readable U.S. Postmark dated on or before the due date, properly addressed to the
Village, with adequate postage prepaid.
Section 7-805 Payment. Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in
the following order: 1) first to the interest due for the applicable period; 2) second to the tax due for
the applicable period; and 3) third to the penalty for the applicable period.
