Article VI Laundries, Laundromats, Dry Cleaning
Establishments and Automatic Dry Cleaners
Section 14-601 Definitions. The following words and terms, when used in this Article, shall have
the meanings indicated:
a. Automatic dry cleaner. Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion
thereof having within such premises one or more automatic dry cleaning machines.
b. Automatic dry cleaning machine. Any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or
fabrics and designed to be used or operated by any person but the owner thereof, or an
employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or contains
Perchlorethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to
human beings by reason of inhalation or contact.
c. Dry cleaning establishment. Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion
thereof used for the purpose of cleaning clothes or fabrics through the use of automatic dry
cleaning machines or any machines or devices using Perchlorethylene or any other
chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of
inhalation or contact.
d. Laundromat. Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof having
one or more self service coin- operated washing machines which are rented, leased or hired
out to the general public for a consideration and for use upon the premises.
e. Laundry. Any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof which is
used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing shirts, dresses, collars, cuffs
or other wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens towels, curtains, draperies,
bedding or other washable fabrics, for the general public.
Section 14-602 License Required. No person shall conduct, operate or maintain a laundry,
laundromat, dry cleaning establishment or automatic dry cleaner in the Village without first having
obtained a license therefor.
Section 14-603 Application. An application for a license to conduct, operate or maintain a
laundry, laundromat, dry cleaning establishment or automatic dry cleaner shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses. The
application for a license to conduct, operate or maintain a laundromat or automatic dry cleaner
shall also state the number of self- service coin- operated machines proposed to be used in said
business for the washing, drying, dry cleaning or other laundry or dry cleaning processes.
Section 14-604 General Regulations Relating to Dry Cleaning Establishments. Every person
licensed to conduct, operate or maintain a dry cleaning establishment shall comply with all
applicable provisions of this Code.
Section 14-605 Sanitation. The premises used for laundries, laundromats, dry cleaning
establishments or automatic dry cleaners must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No refuse
OTHER BUSINESSES
16 REVISED 10/05/09
of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate on such premises and the premises must be kept free
from rats, mice and vermin.
Section 14-606 Installation of Automatic Dry Cleaning Machines. The installation of
automatic dry cleaning machines shall conform with the following regulations:
a. Each machine shall be completely enclosed by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at
the top and the outlet at or near the bottom of each machine. Groups of machines may be
entirely enclosed or supported on all open sides by an enclosure topped with a hood vented
as provided for each individual machine.
b. The exhaust system must maintain a minimum flow of 100 cubic feet per minute face
velocity through the loading door whenever the door is open.
c. The discharge stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines are located
shall extend at least two feet above the level of any window which can be opened located
within 50 feet of the outlet of the stack, and be at least 50 feet away from any fresh intake
leading to any premises.
d. The machines must be constructed so as to prevent the loading door from being opened
during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be equipped with a transparent
door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the cleaning cycle.
e. Any connection of a machine with the water supply system must be equipped with an air
gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the condenser, with no control valves
downstream from the gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap.
f. The room in which the machine is installed shall be ventilated so that there shall be a
minimum flow of air per machine from the area to which the public is admitted of at least
500 cubic feet per minute in a room where there are no more than three machines installed;
400 cubic feet per minute where there are no more than eight machines installed; 375 cubic
feet per minute where there are no more than 16 machines installed; and 360 cubic feet per
minute where there are no more than 17 machines installed. For this purpose, each cleaning
cell shall be considered as one machine.
g. Each machine must be designated and constructed so as to prevent the leakage of liquids,
gas or vapors.
Section 14-607 Ventilation Requirements. No laundry or laundromat shall be conducted or
operated in any room or place in which the clear height between the ceiling and the finished floor
is less than ten feet, or which is not ventilated in accordance with the building provisions of this
Code.
Every room in any laundry or laundromat in which the temperature and humidity might endanger
the health of the persons employed there shall be provided with a mechanical ventilating system
approved by the Director of Health Services and Director of Building.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
17 REVISED 10/05/09
Section 14-608 Plumbing and Drainage Facilities. Every laundry shall be provided with
adequate sanitary plumbing and drainage facilities, and the installation of all drains and plumbing
fixtures shall be in accordance with the requirements of this Code at the time they are installed.
Every watercloset, sink, coin-operated washing machine, or other plumbing fixture installed
therein shall be impermeable, thoroughly sanitary and of an approved type as specified in the
plumbing regulations of this Code.
Section 14-609 Lavatory Facilities. Every laundry shall be provided with sufficient and suitable
lavatory facilities, including approved wash bowls, wash basins or sinks, supplied with hot and
cold running water, soap, clean individual towels and other equipment deemed necessary for the
health and comfort of patrons and the persons employed there.
Section 14-610 Emission of Vapors. Vapors, smoke or odors emanating from any laundry shall
not be permitted at any time to become a nuisance to any portion of the premises in which such
laundry is located, nor to any adjoining or nearby premises.
Section 14-611 Excessive Heat. Every machine or mechanical device in any laundry which is
operated by an employee and which emits excessive heat shall be equipped with proper heat
deflectors, hood and exhaust, or other apparatus that will carry the heat from the room or place in
which it is located.
Section 14-612 Separation of Laundered and Unlaundered Articles. Every person conducting
or operating any laundry shall be required to provide proper facilities and equipment for the
separate handling of clean and soiled articles. No clean or laundered articles shall be allowed to
come in contact with any unlaundered or soiled articles of any kind at any time.
Section 14-613 Sterilization of Articles. No person conducting or operating any laundry in
which wearing apparel, household linens, towels, bedding or any other fabrics are received and
treated through the process of washing, shall remove, or cause to be removed, from such premises,
any laundered article until the same has been thoroughly sterilized either by keeping it in the
washing machine, vat or other vessel provided for that purpose in which the water therein has been
brought to a boiling temperature or maintained at a temperature of 175 degrees Fahrenheit for at
least 20 minutes; or by subjecting it to live steam under pressure; or by keeping it in a drying
house, or drying tumbler, in which the temperature is not less than 215 degrees Fahrenheit for a
period of not less than 15 minutes; or by passing it through any ironing machine where the ironing
surface is at a temperature of not less than 225 degrees Fahrenheit; except in the case of silks,
woolens or other fabrics which would be injured by the foregoing processes, in which event the
same shall be treated with soap, bleach or such other standard disinfectant solutions as shall be
approved by the Director of Health Services.
Section 14-614 Sprinkling Restrictions. No owner, proprietor or manager of any laundry, or
any person employed there, shall be permitted to sprinkle any fabric with any liquid substance
ejected from the mouth, or blown out of any other device coming in contact with the mouth of that
person.
Section 14-615 Exemption. The provisions of this Article relating to laundries and laundromats
shall not apply to any person engaged in doing custom laundry work at his or her home for a
OTHER BUSINESSES
18 REVISED 10/05/09
regular trade, nor to any room or portion thereof, located in a tenement house or other dwelling
in which domestic laundry work is done by or for the occupants of such building exclusively.
Section 14-616 Inspection. The Director of Building shall inspect or cause to be inspected as
often as deemed necessary every laundry, laundromat, dry cleaning establishment and automatic
dry cleaner to determine whether all applicable provisions of this Code are being complied with.
Ord. #09-038)
Article VII Day Care Centers
Section 14-701 State Standards Adopted. The " State of Illinois, Licensing Standards for Day
Care Centers," are adopted as regulations for day care centers located in the Village.
Section 14-702 Definitions. For purposes of this Article, the following words or terms shall have
the meanings indicated:
a. Applicant or Licensee. The corporate body or individual who files an application for a day
care center and who is responsible for the operation and maintenance of the day care center
in accordance with the provisions provided in this Article.
b. Day Care Center. Any institution or place in which are received three or more children,
not of common parentage, apart from their parents or guardian, under the age of six years,
for care during part or all of a day or night, as well as similar units operating under any
other name whatsoever with or without stated educational purposes.
This definition does not include " Group Care Home", " Group Day Care Home", " Foster
Family Home", "Centers for Mentally Retarded" licensed by the State of Illinois, bona fide
kindergartens or " Day Nursery Schools", established in connection with grade schools
supervised or operated by a private or public Board of Education or approved by the State
Department of Public Instruction. The definition includes baby- sitting services in
conjunction with bowling alleys, exercise establishments and such places of business.
c. Director. The person or persons under whose management or supervision the day care
center shall be conducted.
d. Owner. In the case of an individual licensee, it means licensee; in the case of a partnership,
it means each member thereof; and in the case of a corporation, firm or association, it
means the officers thereof.
Section 14-703 License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly
constituted authorities of the United States, the State, the county, or the Village, to conduct or
operate any day care center within the Village without having first obtained a license therefor.
Ord. #09-038)
Section 14-704 Application. An application for a license to conduct and operate a day care
center shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to
applications for licenses. A copy of a valid license issued by the State of Illinois shall be provided
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
19 REVISED 10/05/09
to the Village upon its receipt by the day care center operator. The application shall also contain
the following information:
a. The name, date of birth and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case
of a co-partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in the case of a
corporation, for profit, or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was
organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority interest
of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his or her nominee, the name
and address of such person.
b. The applicant' s current occupation/ employment, business address and telephone number.
c. Any previous arrests or convictions of the applicant for violation( s) of any State Statutes
or local ordinances.
d. The applicant's previous residences for the past five years.
Ord. #09-038)
e. Other identification material for its principal officers and agents to facilitate investigation
by the Police Chief.
f. The location of the day care center for which a license is sought.
g. The number of children to be cared for.
h. The name of the person or persons under whose management or supervision the day care
center will be conducted. The applicant shall notify the Village in writing of a change in
management.
Section 14-705 Fee Exemption. Day care centers which are operated without a charge being
made for the care of children shall be exempt from payment of the license fee. Application for a
license for such a day care center shall be accompanied by an affidavit stating that no charge is
made for the care of the children. After appropriate investigation, any day care center that is not
operated for gain, but where a charge is made for the care of children, shall be exempt from
payment of the license fee for the duration of the license period. All day care centers claiming to
qualify for an exemption pursuant to this provision must provide proof of not- for-profit status from
the State of Illinois.
Section 14-706 Display of License - Transfer. The license shall be displayed in a conspicuous
place near the main entrance inside the day care center. A license shall be valid only in the hands
of the person to whom it is issued and it shall not be subject to sale, assignment or transfer, whether
voluntary or involuntary, nor shall a license be valid for any premises other than those for which
originally issued.
Section 14-707 Denial of License - Revocation of License. A license may be denied or revoked
for any of the following reasons:
a. Violation of any provisions of this Article;
OTHER BUSINESSES
20 REVISED 10/05/09
b. Personnel insufficient in number or unqualified by training or experience to provide proper
and adequate supervision for the number of children to be cared for;
c. Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of a child;
Ord. #09-038)
d. Conviction of the licensee, or if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association of any of
its members, or if a corporation, any of its officers or directors or of the person designated
as director of the day care center, of a felony, or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude
as shown by a record of conviction;
e. In the case of a conviction of a misdemeanor by a court not of record, as shown by other
evidence; or other satisfactory evidence that the moral character of the applicant or director
of the day care center is not reputable;
f. Misappropriation of the property of a child;
g. Denial or revocation of State day care center license;
h. Any ground upon which an application for a license may be denied.
Section 14-708 Rules and Regulations. The premises and facilities used as a day care center
shall comply with the building, zoning, fire, health, and sanitation regulations of this Code.
Section 14-709 Inspection.
a. The Director of Building shall inspect or cause to be inspected as often as deemed
necessary, every day care center to determine whether all applicable provisions of this
Code are being complied with. Whenever an inspection of a day care center discloses that
the continued operation of the day care center would be an immediate and serious menace
to public health and safety, the Village Manager is hereby authorized to close such day
care center.
b. When the Village has reasonable cause to suspect the possibility of disease transmission
from any day care center employee, it shall secure a morbidity history of the suspected
employee or make any other investigation as may be indicated, and take appropriate action.
Any or all of the following may be required:
1. Immediate exclusion of the employee from any activities;
2. Immediate closure of the day care center until, in the opinion of the Village, no
other danger of disease outbreak exists;
3. Restriction of the employee' s services to some area of the establishment where there
will be no danger of transmitting disease.

Article VIII Day Care Homes
Ord. #19-030)
Section 14-801 Definition. A Day Care Home means a family home which receives more than
three up to a maximum of 12 children for less than 24 hours per day. The number counted includes
the family's natural or adopted children and all other persons under the age of 12. The term does
not include facilities which receive only children from a single household.
Section 14-802 License Required. No person shall conduct or operate a day care home without
having first obtained a license from the State of Illinois, pursuant to the provisions of the Child
Care Act of 1969 and a license from the Village.
Section 14-803 Application.
a. Any person desiring to conduct or operate a day care home shall apply for a license to the
Director of Building. The application shall be in writing, with the full name and address
of the applicant and the place where the day care home is to be operated. It shall be
accompanied by a copy of a valid license issued by the State of Illinois.
b. The applicant shall certify on the application that the applicant has established and will
maintain at all times the standards provided for in the Illinois Child Care Act of 1969, as
amended; that the Village may inspect the child day care home at any reasonable time; and
that the applicant will install smoke detectors within the home at all locations designated
by the Arlington Heights Fire Department.
Section 14-804 Notification of Surrounding Property Owners. Upon receipt of an application
for a license for a day care home, the applicant shall be required to notify the owners of the property
contiguous to the applicant' s home, which shall include property to the front, both sides and rear,
and the property abutting those properties if any point is contiguous to the property of the applicant.
The neighbor fronting on the streets directly across from the subject property shall also be notified.
Notification may be by one of two methods at the election of the applicant: a form letter furnished
by the Village and completed by the applicant may be sent by certified mail, advising surrounding
owners that a license will be issued 15 days after the date of notice if no written objection is
received by that date; or the applicant may present a form letter furnished by the Village, with the
signature of each surrounding owner acknowledging receipt of such notice by a personal visit from
the applicant.
In the event a written objection is received, the Village Manager shall conduct an administrative
hearing with written notice of the time and place of the hearing no less than ten days nor more than
30 days after receipt of the written objection. Notice of the administrative hearing will be sent by
certified mail to the applicant and all surrounding owners. At the hearing the complainant shall
show cause why the proposed operation of a day care home should not be permitted and why the
license should not be issued. The license shall be denied only upon showing by the objector that
the operation would violate a Village Ordinance or State Statute, would constitute a nuisance or
would substantially change the character of the neighborhood. Any party who received notice of
the hearing will be afforded an opportunity to be heard. A written record of the hearing will be
made and the decision of the Village Manager forwarded with the written record to the Board of
OTHER BUSINESSES
14-22 REVISED 10/05/09
Trustees and all the parties within ten days after the hearing. Any party who received notice of
the hearing may appeal the decision of the Village Manager to the Board of Trustees within 30
days of the date of the decision; otherwise the decision of the Village Manager will be final. All
decisions by the Board of Trustees on appeals will be final.
Section 14-805 Issuance of License and Notice. The Village Manager shall issue a license for
a day care home upon compliance with the following:
a. Verification of the validity of the applicant' s State of Illinois license;
b. Inspection by the Fire Department for verification that the required smoke detectors have
been installed and for compliance with all fire regulations;
c. Notification of surrounding property owners and favorable completion of the hearing
procedure, if required;
d. Payment of the appropriate license fee.
Section 14-806 Renewal. Each day care home license shall be renewed annually as of January
1. The requirements for renewal are:
a. Verification of the validity of the applicant's State of Illinois license;
b. Inspection by the Fire Department and compliance with all fire regulations;
c. Payment of the appropriate license fee.
Section 14-807 Revocation of License. If, at any time after the granting of the license required
by this Article, the licensee fails to comply with any of the provisions of this Code, or a complaint
is received that the conduct of the day care home constitutes a nuisance, a public hearing shall be
scheduled after written notice as provided in Section 14-804, Notification of Surrounding Property
Owners, above, at which the complainant shall show cause why the license should be revoked.
Written notice and a record of the hearing and the appeal procedure shall be the same as provided
for in Section 14-804 above.
Ord. #09-038)
Article IX Machine Shops
Section 14-901 Definition. Machine shop, when used in this Article, shall mean a workshop in
which a machine shop business is conducted and in which machines are made or metal parts thereof
are repaired for the public, or in which parts of machines, or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws
or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped, punched, stamped or repaired by means of a lathe or
other machinery for the public.
Section 14-902 License Required. No person shall conduct or operate a machine shop within
the Village without first having obtained a license therefor, unless the machine shop is specifically
licensed under other provisions of this Code.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
23 REVISED 10/05/09
Section 14-903 Application. An application for a license shall be made in conformance with the
general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses. The application shall also
state the number of employees or other persons engaged or to be engaged in the machine shop.
Section 14-904 Location. No machine shop shall be conducted or operated on any lot or plot of
ground any portion of which is within 200 feet of any lot occupied by a public or parochial school,
hospital or church.
Section 14-905 Operation at Night. No machine shop shall be operated in the night time between
the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in any block in which a majority of the buildings on both
sides of the street are used exclusively for residential purposes, or within 100 feet of such block,
and it shall be within the power of the Director of Health Services, after reasonable notice, to treat
such night operation as a public nuisance and to abate the same.
Section 14-906 Sanitary and Health Requirements. No building, structure or part thereof used
for or in connection with any machine shop shall be used so as to endanger the health or property
of the employees or of the public. Machine shops shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
a. The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager of any such machine shop shall cause all
floors and other surfaces around or beneath any machine or work bench to be kept in good
order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving
waste and cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines
or parts thereof or which are intended for any other necessary use. The owner, lessee,
tenant, occupant, or manager shall not permit any steel cuttings or machine parts to
accumulate on or about any machine or work bench so as to become detrimental to the
health or safety of any person therein engaged.
b. The Director of Health Services shall visit or cause to be visited all such machine shops
within the Village as often as deemed necessary to ascertain whether the regulations
governing machine shops are complied with, and to analyze any cutting compound used in
connection with the machine shop work where any cutting compound is to be re-used. If,
upon such analysis, the Director of Health Services finds that the cutting fluid is in any
way contaminated, and as a result of such contamination may infect any employee of the
machine shop, the Director of Health Services shall immediately take the necessary steps
to prevent the further use of such cutting compound or fluid or order a proper treatment to
eliminate from such cutting fluid or compound any further danger of contamination to
employees.
c. In every machine shop where the employees are permitted to eat on the premises, a suitable
place shall be provided for that purpose, and every place provided shall be kept thoroughly
clean and proper receptacles shall be furnished for the collection of refuse.
d. It shall be the duty of the Director of Health Services to cause an inspection to be made of
the premises used for machine shop purposes and all buildings used in connection
therewith as often as may be necessary to abate or cause to be removed any violation.

24 REVISED 10/05/09
Section 14-907 Noise. It shall be unlawful to operate a machine shop where pneumatic hammers
or other apparatus are used which cause loud or unusual noises, within 200 feet of any residence.

Article X Nursing Homes
Section 14-1001 Definition. Nursing home, when used in this Article, shall mean any institution,
place or residence used for the reception or care, for a longer period than 24 hours of three or more
children or infants apart from their parents; or any institution used for the reception or care of
persons who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall include
homes for the aged or infirm, orphan asylums, refuges and shelters, and boarding homes caring for
three or more women and their children when the children are less than 14 years of age.
Section 14-1002 License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the regularly
constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the Village or the State of Illinois, or any
association or institution for the care of children which has been accredited, certified or licensed
by the State of Illinois pursuant to an act of the legislature, to regulate the treatment and control of
dependent, neglected and delinquent children, to open, conduct, manage or maintain any nursing
home, as defined in this Article, within the Village, without first having obtained a license therefor.
Section 14-1003 Application. An application for a license to conduct and operate a nursing home
shall be made in conformance with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications
for licenses. The application shall state the location or proposed location of the nursing home, the
purpose for which it is to be opened, conducted or maintained, the accommodations for the
residents, the nature and kind of care, instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given therein,
the name and address of the officials and/ or board of officials conducting, managing or maintaining
the nursing home, the name of the superintendent or person in charge of the nursing home, the
name and address of the chief physician, surgeon or attending physician or surgeon, or the names
and addresses of the board of physicians or surgeons attending therein if there is such a board.
Section 14-1004 General Regulations. In addition to the regulations herein set forth, each
nursing home shall comply with at least the minimum requirements established by the Department
of Public Health pursuant to the Nursing Home Care Act, as the minimum requirements may be
amended from time to time and in effect.
Section 14-1005 Inspections. The Director of Building shall inspect or cause to be inspected as
often as deemed necessary every nursing home in the Village to determine if it is in compliance
with all applicable provisions of this Code.
Section 14-1006 Penalty. In the event of a conviction of any person for a violation of any of the
provisions of this Article relating to the safety and accommodations of residents, the Village
Manager is hereby authorized and empowered to close such nursing home and to cause the
vacation pending the repairs, alterations or additions necessary to make it safe and proper for the
occupancy of its residents and to make it comply with the terms of this Article.

Article XI Bill Posting and Sign Painting
Section 14-1101 Definition. Bill poster and sign painter, when used in this Article, shall mean
any person engaged in the business or occupation of posting by tacking, pasting, painting,
demonstrating or otherwise distributing upon the public ways any advertising matter, bills, posters,
pictures or any other matter or device whatever which advertises the business of any person,
whether that of merchant, manufacturer, publisher or person engaged in any business or industrial
pursuit, or any operas, theaters, shows, circuses or other exhibitions, excepting those intended for
charitable purposes; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be considered to apply
to the painting of a store or office sign by sign painters, or to posting of legal notices by public
officers or attorneys in the manner and in the places prescribed by law, or to persons who are in
the business of distributing circulars, handbills or business cards by placing them inside of the
doors of dwellings or buildings within the Village.
Section 14-1102 License Required. No person shall engage in the business of billposting or sign
painting in the Village without first having obtained a license therefor. No license issued under
this Article shall, however, be construed as permitting the use for advertising purposes of any
structures, natural or artificial, which are located in any public street, alley or other public place.
Section 14-1103 Application. An application for a license shall be made in conformity with the
general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses. The application shall also
state the place or places, including billboards or natural structures, on which the applicant intends
to place advertisements.
Section 14-1104 Obscene Pictures. No person engaging in the business of bill posting or sign
painting shall post or cause to be posted any advertisement containing pictures or illustrations of
an obscene character.
Section 14-1105 Use of Poster Panels. No person shall post or maintain any advertisement or
sign on any poster panel, billboard or signboard which does not fully comply with the applicable
provisions of this Code.
Section 14-1106 Consent of Owner. It shall be unlawful to post any advertisements on any
premises in the Village without the consent of the owner of such premises. Such consent must be
in writing.
Section 14-1107 Refuse. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in bill posting or sign
painting to permit any refuse resulting from this work to accumulate anywhere in the Village, and
it shall be the duty of such person to cart away and properly dispose of any such refuse. It shall
be unlawful to permit any loose, flapping or combustible materials to hang from or be attached to
any automobile, billboard, or signboard or other place used for advertising purposes. All refuse
resulting from the operation of this business must be carefully gathered up and disposed of
properly.
Section 14-1108 Weeds and Materials at Base of Billboards. It shall be the duty of every bill
poster or sign painter to keep all grass, weeds and other growths, except trees and ornamental
shrubbery, cut down so that the same shall not grow to a height greater than 12 inches within six
OTHER BUSINESSES
26 REVISED 10/05/09
feet of any billboard or signboard used by him; provided that this obligation shall extend only to
property controlled by the bill poster or sign painter.
Section 14-1109 Disfiguring Signs. It shall be unlawful to mutilate or disfigure in any way any
lawful sign or advertisements in the Village.
Section 14-1110 Identification. It shall be unlawful for any bill poster or sign painter to engage
in that business unless his or her name is attached, displayed or printed on all billboards, signboards
or advertisement he or she uses, in lettering so as to be visible from a distance of at least five feet
from the billboard, sign board or advertisement.
Section 14-1111 Inspection. The Director of Building shall inspect or cause to be inspected as
often as deemed necessary the activities of every bill poster or sign painter in the Village to
determine whether all applicable provisions of this Code are being complied with.
Section 14-1112 Construction of Article. Nothing in this Article shall be considered as limiting
any provision of Chapter 30, Sign Regulations, of this Code.

Article XII Solid Waste Contractors
Section 14-1201 Definitions. The following words and terms shall have the meanings indicated:
a. Solid waste contractor. Any person engaged in the removal and disposal of garbage,
refuse, recyclable material, landscape waste and white goods. It shall also include any
person engaged in the above- described business and activities, whether such service is
provided for homeowners or commercial, business and industrial establishments.
b. Sewer and catch-basin cleaner. Any person engaging in the business of cleaning, collecting
or transporting the contents of catch basins or sewers or kindred refuse by vehicle or
otherwise, or in any manner engaging in the business of cleaning catch basins and sewers;
provided, however, that licensed plumbers or licensed sewer builders who may clean catch
basins or sewers as an incident to the repair of such catch basins or sewers shall not be
required to obtain a license hereunder.
Section 14-1202 License Required.
a. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of removal of solid waste
without first having obtained a license thereto.
b. Only one residential solid waste contractor license shall be issued for the purpose of
performing solid waste collection from single- family residential property; that to the
person awarded the contract with the Village.
c. There is no limitation on the number of licenses issued for servicing commercial facilities
and multiple- family residences of four or more units. A license for this purpose will be
issued to each qualified applicant who presents evidence that he or she has adequate and
proper equipment and approved disposal facilities.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
27 REVISED 10/05/09
Section 14-1203 Application. An application for a license hereunder shall be made in
conformance with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses. The
application shall also state the number of vehicles used in the applicant's business.
Section 14-1204 General Regulations.
a. Any person licensed under this Article shall comply strictly with the regulations of Chapter
19. Article II, Health and Sanitation – Nuisances, of this Code, relating to solid waste, as
well as all other applicable provisions of this Code relating to health and sanitation.
b. Persons holding a commercial solid waste contractor license shall complete a written
service agreement with each customer or premises serviced to include, at a minimum, the
name of the customer, address, frequency of service and size of container provided.
Section 14-1205 Other Requirements. It shall be the duty of every licensee hereunder who has
undertaken to remove any solid waste, to do the same with dispatch and in every particular in a
manner as cleanly and free from offense and with as little damage and prejudice to life and health
as possible.
Section 14-1206 Inspection. The Director of Building shall inspect or cause to be inspected as
often as deemed necessary, the vehicles and methods of doing business utilized by each licensee
hereunder to determine whether there is compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code.
Section 14-1207 Provision of Recycling Services Required.
a. As a condition of receiving, maintaining, and renewing a solid waste contractor' s license
within the Village, each licensee serving a multi-family property shall establish and
maintain the capability of providing recycling collection services to multi- family
properties in the Village, either directly or pursuant to a subcontract with a licensed solid
waste contractor as required by applicable provisions of the Code. Solid waste contractors
not serving multi-family properties shall be exempt from this requirement.
b. A license certification form shall be submitted to the Village in conjunction with an
application for the issuance or renewal of a solid waste contractor' s license. The format of
the form shall be as prescribed by the Village for the purpose of obtaining information
reasonably necessary to determine the applicant' s capabilities to perform the required
recycling collection services. The Village shall review the information, and may inspect
the applicant' s processing facilities to determine such capabilities. Approval of the form
shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of the license.
c. Each licensee serving a multi-family property and providing recycling collection services,
shall sign an annual affidavit form provided by the Village. The affidavit shall indicate
that the recyclable materials are not being land filled, incinerated or otherwise destroyed
by the licensee or by any other entity purchasing or receiving the recyclable materials
collected at multi-family properties located within the Village. Furthermore, the affidavit
shall indicate that the recyclable materials have been taken to a recycler of that commodity.

28 REVISED 10/05/09
2
Section 14-1208 Industrial or Commercial Recycling. All scavengers licensed by the Village
to service industrial or commercial properties in the Village shall, as part of their licensing
requirements, offer a recycling program to their customers on an annual basis. At a minimum, the
recycling program offered shall include the following: office paper, cardboard and glass and
aluminum containers. The scavenger shall process, store and market all of the recyclable materials
collected to an end-user, and shall not landfill or incinerate any of the recyclable materials.
The scavenger shall also be required to deliver to each customer, information on the type of
program they offer and the items they include for recycling. All promotional materials must be
approved by the Village Health Services Department. Customers shall be kept informed, on an
annual basis, of any additional recyclable items offered.
The licensed scavenger shall furnish annual totals to the Village, for the purpose of monitoring
compliance with this Section, indicating the number of customers participating in the recycling
program and the amount of materials recycled, estimated in weight or volume.
The scavenger may, as an option, contract with a secondary scavenger licensed with the Village to
administer the industrial or commercial recycling program. The licensed scavenger shall be
responsible for furnishing, maintaining and replacing all recycling containers and vehicles deemed
necessary in the recycling program.
Section 14-1209 Penalty. Any scavenger business violating any of the provisions of Section 14-
1208, Industrial or Commercial Recycling, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $ 50 nor more
than $750 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
which a violation occurs or continues to exist. In addition to any fines, the Village may enjoin the
operation of any scavenger business being conducted in violation of Section 14-1208 or proceed
to revoke the license.
Article XIII Public Passenger Vehicles
Section 14-1301 Intent and Purpose.
a. To encourage the best possible public passenger vehicle service under a competitive
system with regulation only to the extent necessary to protect the safety and welfare of the
citizens.
b. To assure that any and all legitimate, locally based public passenger vehicles businesses
are allowed to operate as many vehicles as are economically feasible by placing no limit
on the number of vehicles operated by each business.
c. To assure that public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village are clean, comfortable and
safe.
d. To assure that public passenger vehicle operations are reputable, capable and safe.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
29
e. To assure that only bona fide public passenger vehicles licensed by the Village are
permitted to offer their services on the streets, at taxicab stands, at residences and at places
of business in the Village.
In order to accomplish the purposes listed above, the Village requires a business license, a local
Village license for each public passenger vehicle and a local Village operator's license for each
driver. The intent of these regulations is to protect each driver and consumer interests by providing
for periodic inspections of vehicles to maintain mechanical dependability and setting minimum
requirements for competent operators.
Section 14-1302 Definitions. For the purposes of this Article, the following words and phrases
shall have the meanings set forth below:
a. Dispatch Office. A central place of business for the purpose of receiving calls and
dispatching vehicles.
b. Inspection Station. A facility designated by the Police Chief to conduct inspections
required by this Article.
c. Licensee. Licensee shall mean any person who is the owner of one or more licenses issued
pursuant to this Article.
d. Livery Vehicle. Any public passenger vehicle transporting passengers for hire, as a result
of individual contract, on a trip or hourly basis fixed in advance.
e. Person. Any natural person, corporation, partnership, unincorporated association or other
legal entity.
f. Public Passenger Vehicles. Taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transportation of
passengers for hire.
g. Public Passenger Vehicle Chauffeur. Any person who drives a public passenger vehicle
in use for the transportation of persons for compensation.
h. Public Passenger Vehicle Company. Any person engaged in business as proprietor of one
or more public passenger vehicles for transportation of passengers for hire.
i. Public Passenger Vehicle Owner. Any person owning or leasing from another, a public
passenger vehicle for hire.
j. Taxicab. Any motor-propelled vehicle equipped with a taximeter and operated for
transportation of passengers for hire, available indiscriminately to all persons as may offer
themselves for transportation.
k. Taxicab Stand. Any place, public or private, where taxicabs are placed on display and
presented for hire to prospective customers, accepting such persons as may offer
OTHER BUSINESSES
30
themselves for transportation. Examples of taxicab stands are: railroad stations, hotels,
motels, bowling alleys, theaters, race tracks and any prominent gathering place.
l. Taximeter. Any mechanical or electronic device attached to a taxicab which records and
indicates a charge or fare in dollars and cents measured by distance and waiting time.
m. Waiting time. The time when the taxicab is not in motion, beginning with the arrival at
the place to which it has been called, or the time consumed while standing at the direction
of the passenger, but no charge shall be made for the time lost on account of inefficiency
of the taxicab, or its operator, or time consumed by a premature response to a call.
Section 14-1303 Business License
a. No public passenger vehicle company shall maintain a place of business, including a
dispatch office, in the Village without first having obtained a business license.
Ord. #04-077, # 06-078)
b. Application. The business license application, accompanied by a non- returnable fee of
40, will contain the same information required by the Village for all businesses, and be
accompanied by a letter providing all of the following additional information, as
applicable, if not on the standard application form:
1. The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case
of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in the case
of a corporation, for profit, or a club, the state and date of incorporation, the objects
for which it was organized, names and addresses of the officers and directors, and

10. The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the
location of proposed depots and terminals;
11. The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle or vehicles of the
applicant, which color scheme and insignia, shall be readily distinguishable from
that of emergency vehicles and vehicles of previously licensed public passenger

12. Such further information as may be required by the Village Manager.

Clerk. If any insurance is canceled or permitted to lapse for any reason, the Village

exceed 30 days, to permit other insurance to be supplied in compliance with the
provisions of this Section. If such other insurance is not supplied with the period
of suspension of the license, the Village Manager shall revoke the license for such
vehicles.
d. Issuance. If the Village Manager finds that the applicant conforms to the provisions of this
Article, and that the application and background investigation reveal nothing of a nature
that might endanger the health, safety and welfare of the general public as a result of the
applicant's possession of a license, then the Village Manager shall issue a business license
upon receipt of the first year' s license fee.
e. Non- transferable. No business license may be sold, assigned, mortgaged, pledged or
otherwise transferred.
f. Suspension or Revocation. The business license may be suspended or revoked by the
Village Manager if the licensee has:
1. Failed to keep in force the insurance required by this Section;
2. Discontinued operations in the Village for more than 30 days; or
OTHER BUSINESSES

3. Violated any ordinances of the Village or the laws of the United States of America
or the State of Illinois, related to the fitness of the licensee to offer public
transportation.
At least 30 days prior to suspension or revocation, the licensee shall be given written notice
of the proposed action, and shall have an opportunity to be heard by the Village Manager
during such period.
g. Appeal. Any applicant who has been denied a license or any licensee whose license is
suspended or revoked by the Village Manager shall have an opportunity for hearing in the
manner provided by Sections 9-107, Approval; Disapproval and 9-403, Revocation of
Licenses, Suspension of Licenses, Notice and Hearings, of this Code.
h. Change in Stock Ownership.
1. A corporation holding a public passenger business license shall advise the Village
Manager 30 days prior to any contemplated change of stock ownership involving
5% or more of the stock of the corporation.
2. Each individual seeking to acquire5% or more of the stock of a corporation holding
a public passenger vehicle license shall comply with the provisions of this Section
as though he or she were applying for a license as an individual.
3. The provisions of this paragraph do not apply to corporations whose stock is traded
publicly and listed on recognized stock exchanges.
Section 14-1304 Operation of Business.
a. Regular Telephone Service Required. Every public passenger vehicle business licensee
shall keep in service at all times while the license is in effect, regular telephone service
within the Village by means of which a person desiring to hire a public passenger vehicle
may call the licensee. The licensee shall cause the telephone number to be listed in the
local and regional telephone directories which are published for the Municipality by the
telephone company which furnishes local telephone service in the Municipality.
b. Public Passenger Service. Each public passenger vehicle business licensee shall operate
every public passenger vehicle regularly in the Village to the extent reasonably necessary
to meet the public demands for passenger service. They shall maintain in the Village a
central place of business for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching vehicles. They
shall answer all calls received by them for service inside the corporate limits of the
Municipality as soon as they can do so and if service cannot be rendered within a
reasonable time, they shall notify the prospective passengers how long it will be before the
call can be answered and give the reason therefor. Any licensee who shall refuse to accept
a call anywhere within the corporate limits of the Municipality at any time when such
licensee has available vehicles, or who shall fail to refuse to give over- all service, shall be
deemed in violation of this Article.

Section 14-1305 Public Passenger Vehicle License.
a. Required. It shall be unlawful to operate a public passenger vehicle for hire within the
corporate limits of the Village unless the vehicle is licensed by the Village or another
municipality which cooperates with the Village and is operated, in accordance with the
provisions of this Article.
b. Application. Applications for public passenger vehicle licenses shall be made by the owner
upon forms furnished by the Village. Such applications shall contain the full name and
address of the owner of the vehicle, and in the case of a corporation or partnership, the
names and addresses of the officers or partners; a complete description of the vehicle,
including make and model, vehicle identification number, manufacturer's identification
number, seating capacity ( excluding driver' s seat or any part thereof), a State license
number, color of vehicle, vehicle engine horsepower and such other data as the Village
may require to assure compliance with the requirements of this Article.
c. Insurance. The application for a public passenger vehicle license shall be accompanied by
evidence of the liability insurance required in Section 14-1303(c), Business License -
Insurance.
d. Inspection. The vehicle for which a license application is made shall be inspected as
provided in Section 14-1307, Inspection Stations.
e. Issuance. The Village Clerk shall issue a public passenger vehicle license after the vehicle
has passed the inspection and the license fee has been paid.
Ord. #96-058)
f. Display Required. The number vehicle license decal shall be affixed to the certified
inspection plate, which shall be visibly displayed in the lower left hand corner of the rear
window of the public passenger vehicle.
g. Non- transferable. It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle license from
one vehicle to another. Transferring any public passenger vehicle license shall be grounds
for revocation of all licenses issued pursuant to this Article ( business license, vehicle
licenses and chauffeur licenses) to both the owner of the license and the vehicle to which
the license is transferred.
Section 14-1306 Inspection. The Police Chief will cause inspection of all licensed public
passenger vehicles to be done three times a year, except those second division vehicles or
limousines displaying a certificate of safety issued pursuant to the Motor Vehicle Code of the State
of Illinois.
a. After receiving a notice from the Police Chief or designee, a public passenger vehicle
company will be allowed seven days to take their licensed public passenger vehicles to an
inspection station for inspection. The license of all public passenger vehicles not inspected
within that period will be suspended by the direction of the Village Manager.
b. Such inspection will include, but need not be limited to, the following:
OTHER BUSINESSES
34 REVISED 10/05/09
1. Vehicle, make, year and vehicle identification number,
2. State license number and year,
3. Village vehicle license number and year,
4. Vehicle color,
5. Vehicle number,
6. Company name,
7. Service brakes,
8. Emergency brakes,
9. Horn,
10. Rear view mirror,
11. Windshield wipers and washers,
12. Headlights,
13. Tail lights,
14. Stop lights,
15. Turn signals,
16. Speedometer,
17. Taximeter,
18. Rates displayed,
19. Steering,
20. Interior condition,
21. Exterior condition,
22. Windows,
23. Tires,
24. Current bond sticker.
c. Any public passenger vehicle failing to pass the inspection will be given a period of five
working days to allow for repairs. The vehicle cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle
for hire until repairs have been completed and it passes reinspection. If the public
passenger vehicle does not pass reinspection within the five working day period, the public
passenger vehicle license will be suspended by direction of the Village Manager.
d. The Police Chief shall prescribe reasonable standards which public passenger vehicles
must satisfy to pass the inspections required prior to licensing and periodically thereafter,
which standards shall be designed to assure that public passenger vehicles licensed by the
Village are mechanically dependable, safe, clean and satisfy the requirements of this
Article.
Ord. #09-038)
Section 14-1307 Inspection Stations.
a. The Police Chief shall designate those facilities which may serve as inspection stations to
conduct the vehicle inspections required by this Article, which stations may be within or
without the Village. The Chief shall establish procedures for conducting the inspections
and minimum standards for a vehicle to be approved. The Chief shall supply inspection
stations with certified inspection forms, numbered certified vehicle inspection stickers and
such other supplies as may be required to perform the duties required by this Article and
the regulations established hereunder. The inspection station shall notify the Police Chief
of any failure to pass the inspection or reinspection.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
35 REVISED 10/05/09
b. A list of authorized inspection stations shall be kept by the Police Chief and shall be given
to each public passenger vehicle owner together with the notice that the vehicles must be
inspected. An owner may use the authorized inspection station of his or her choice.
c. Inspection stations shall charge the inspection fee authorized by the Police Chief for all
public passenger vehicle inspections. There shall be no charge for a reinspection within
the five working days allowed for repairs to a vehicle that fails the inspection. The
authorized inspection fee shall be charged for a reinspection made after the five working
day grace period.
d. The Police Chief shall cause unannounced spot checks of authorized inspection stations to
ensure compliance with the inspection procedures, standards and fees, and shall investigate
all complaints of misconduct by inspection stations or their employees. Noncompliance
with the requirements of this Article or the regulations established by the Chief shall be
cause for suspension or revocation of the designation as an authorized inspection station
in the manner provided by Section 9-403, Revocation of Licenses, Suspension of Licenses,
Notice and Hearings, of this Code.
e. If the Police Chief shall be satisfied that the applicant satisfies the requirements set forth
in subsection ( d) above, and is a fit person to be licensed, such application shall be
approved and the license issued.
f. It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle chauffeur' s license from one
person to another. Transference of such license shall be grounds for revocation.
g. The Village Manager, in his or her discretion, may suspend a public passenger vehicle
chauffeur' s license for a period not to exceed 30 days, for any failure or refusal to comply
with the provisions of this Article; for any violation of Federal, State or municipal law;
upon a determination that a license was obtained fraudulently, that the licensee has become
physically, mentally or emotionally unfit to serve as a public passenger vehicle operator or
that there has been any fraudulent use of the public passenger vehicle chauffeur' s license
by or with the consent of the licensee, in the manner provided by Sections 9-403,
Revocation of Licenses, Suspension of Licenses, Notice and Hearings, of this Code.
Section 14-1308 Miscellaneous Vehicle Regulations.
a. Every licensed taxicab shall bear on both sides of the vehicle, in lettering contrasting with
the color of the vehicle and not less than two inches in height, the name of the cab company
and its telephone number.
b. The identification number assigned to such vehicle by the taxicab company shall appear
on both exterior sides of the vehicle in Arabic numerals a minimum of three inches in
height and in a conspicuous location within the passenger compartment, in numerals four
inches in height.
c. No taxicab shall be painted or labeled so as to be so similar to the vehicles of any other
person licensed and engaged in the business of operating taxicabs in the Village so as to be
OTHER BUSINESSES
36
an imitation thereof and calculated to deceive the patrons of taxicabs into believing that
such vehicles are in reality the taxicabs of such other person. No taxicab shall be painted
so as to be similar to law enforcement vehicles or the vehicles of any other person.
d. If after the inspection and approval of any public passenger vehicle, as provided for in this
Article, such public passenger vehicle shall from any cause become unsafe for the
transportation of passengers or shall become unclean or unsightly in appearance, the
license of such public passenger vehicle shall be suspended by Village Manager until the
public passenger vehicle and all its accessories shall be put in fit condition for public use
and have been approved and inspected as provided in this Article.
Section 14-1309 Chauffeur License.
a. Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any public passenger vehicle for
hire within the Village without first having obtained a valid public passenger vehicle
chauffeur's license.
b. Owner Responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any public
passenger vehicle to employ or permit any person to operate such vehicle for hire within
the Village unless such driver has a valid public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license
issued by the Village.
c. Application. The application for a license as a public passenger vehicle chauffeur shall
contain the name of the applicant; residence and employment history; number and current
status of the applicant’ s Illinois driver' s license; whether the applicant' s State driver' s
license has ever been suspended or revoked and, if so, when and for what cause; a list of
all convictions, if any, for violation of Federal, State or municipal laws; two personal
references, unrelated to the applicant.
d. Qualifications.
1. Every applicant for a public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license shall be at least
18 years of age.
2. The applicant must pass a physical examination by a licensed medical doctor, at his
or her own expense, subject to the examination conditions on the form provided by
the Village. Such certificate sets forth the opinion of the examining physician that
the applicant is physically able to engage in the driving of public passenger vehicles
without risk to the public.
3. The applicant must be the holder of a valid State of Illinois driver' s license.
4. The applicant must not have been convicted of any felony or Class A misdemeanor
within the past five years.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
37 REVISED 12/20/04
5. The applicant must not have had his or her driver's license suspended or revoked in
any state within the past three years as a consequence of violations of law
concerning the operation of a motor vehicle.
Ord. #04-077)
e. Investigation. Upon filing of the application and payment of the $35 fee, the Police Chief
shall make or cause to be made a careful and diligent investigation, including fingerprinting
of applicant. The report of the investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of
the applicant, if any, shall be considered in evaluating the application.
f. Issuance. If the Police Chief shall be satisfied that the applicant satisfies the requirements
set forth in this Section, and is a fit person to be licensed, such application shall be approved
and the license issued.
g. Display. The chauffeur' s license shall be displayed at all times in the public passenger
vehicle in plain view of the passenger.
h. Non- transferable. It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle chauffeur' s
license from one person to another. Transferring a license shall be grounds for revocation.
i. Suspension or Revocation. The Village Manager, in his or her discretion, may suspend a
public passenger vehicle chauffeur' s license for a period not to exceed 30 days, for any
failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this Article; for any violation of Federal,
State or municipal law; upon a determination that the license was obtained fraudulently,
that the licensee has become physically, mentally or emotionally unfit to perform his duties
as a public passenger vehicle operator, or that there has been any fraudulent use of the
public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license by or with the consent of the licensee, in the
manner provided by Sections 9-403, Revocation of Licenses, Suspension of Licenses,
Notice and Hearings, of this Code.
Section 14-1310 Public Passenger Vehicle Operation.
a. No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall carry more than the rated passenger load
per vehicle.
b. After a public passenger vehicle has been hired by one or more persons traveling together,
the operator shall not pick up other persons without the express permission of the person
or persons first engaging the public passenger vehicle. An appropriate sign shall be posted
indicating the restrictions on shared rides.
c. No driver of a public passenger vehicle shall seek employment by repeatedly or
persistently driving his or her vehicle to and fro in a short space before any theater, hotel,
railway station or other public place or by otherwise interfering with the proper and orderly
access to or egress from any such place.
d. The operator or person in charge or control of any taxicab may demand, in advance, the
payment of the fare of the person desiring to be carried by such taxicab, and may refuse to
convey any person who shall not comply with the demand; but no driver or operator of a
OTHER BUSINESSES
38 REVISED 06/16/08
taxicab shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request,
anywhere in the Village, unless previously engaged or unable to do so.
e. Advertising is restricted to that which may be displayed on a light mounted on top of the
vehicle.
Section 14-1311 Operation of Livery Vehicles.
a. Livery vehicles shall not pick up or solicit passengers for hire from the streets.
b. Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab stands.
c. Livery vehicles shall not indiscriminately accept passengers, but shall be limited in scope
of operation to carrying passengers for hire on a contract basis at a price agreed upon prior
to employment and by arrangement of the parties at the time of initial telephone contact by
customer to the livery company.
Ord. #98-053, # 08-018)

Section 14-1313 Posting Established Rates. There shall be affixed inside each taxicab in a place

material, a rate card issued by the Village, upon which card shall be printed in plain, legible type ,
the rates of fare as prescribed by Section 14-1312, Taxicab Rates.
