and procedures, and the daily operation of the administrative adjudication of parking and
compliance violations program.
Section 18-803 Hearing Officer Appointed. A Hearing Officer shall be appointed who shall be
empowered and directed to:
a. Preside over the administrative hearings established herein, as the adjudicator;
b. Administer oaths;
c. Issue subpoenas to secure the attendance of witnesses and production of relevant papers or
documentation;
d. Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the existence of the code violation;
e. Assess fines and penalties for violations as established in the Village Code;
f. Make final determinations of violation liability;
g. Provide for the accurate recordation of the administrative adjudication system.
Section 18-804 Violation - Penalty. The violation of any provision of the traffic prohibiting or
restricting vehicular standing or parking, or establishing a compliance violation, shall be a civil
offense punishable by fine only.
Section 18-805 Prima Facie Responsibility for Violation and Penalty – Parking Violation
Issuance and Removal.
a. Whenever any vehicle exhibits a compliance violation or is parked in violation of any
provision of any applicable provision of Article II, Parking, of Chapter 18 of the Arlington
Heights Municipal Code prohibiting or restricting vehicular parking or standing, any
person in whose name the vehicle is registered with the Secretary of State of Illinois or
such other state’ s registry of motor vehicles shall be prima facie responsible for the
violation and subject to the penalty therefore. The Village and the police officer shall
accurately record the state registration number of the ticketed vehicle.
TRAFFIC
32 REVISED 02/15/10
b. For purposes of Section 17-103, Vehicle License Required, of the Arlington Heights
Municipal Code, a prima facie case shall not be established when the registered owner was
not a resident of the Village of Arlington Heights on the day the violation was issued.
c. Whenever any vehicle exhibits a compliance violation during operation or is parked in
violation of any provision of Article II, Parking, of Chapter 18 of the Arlington Heights
Municipal Code prohibiting or restricting vehicular parking or standing or regulating the
condition of a parked or standing vehicle, any police officer, public service officer or other
person designated by the Police Chief observing such violation may issue a parking or
compliance violation notice, as provided for in the Arlington Heights Municipal Code and
serve the notice on the owner of the vehicle by handing it to the operator of the vehicle, if
present, or by affixing it to the vehicle in a conspicuous place.
d. The issuer of the notice shall specify on the notice his identification number, the particular
parking or compliance ordinance allegedly violated, the make and state registration number
of the cited vehicle, and the place, date and time of the alleged violation, the fine and any
penalty that may be assessed for late payment and shall certify the correctness of the
specified information by signing his name as provided in Section 11-208.3 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, as now or hereafter amended.
e. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner of the vehicle or his designee, to
remove, from a vehicle a parking or compliance violation notice affixed pursuant to the
ordinance codified in the Municipal Code.
Section 18-806 Violation Notices – Contents, Distribution and Record Keeping.
a. In addition to the information set forth above, the notices shall state the applicable fine as
provided in Chapter 18 of the Municipal Code, the monetary penalty which shall be
automatically assessed for late payment, a statement that vehicle immobilization and
driver’ s license suspension ( if applicable) may be imposed if fines and penalties are not
paid in full, that payment of the indicated fine, and of any applicable penalty for late
payment, shall operate as a final disposition of the violation, and information as to the
availability of an administrative hearing in which the violation may be contested on its
merits and the time and manner in which such hearing may be had.
b. The Traffic Compliance Officer shall distribute parking and compliance violation notices
to all persons authorized to issue parking and compliance violating notices.
c. The Traffic Compliance Officer shall compile and maintain complete and accurate records
relating to all parking violation notices issued pursuant to this Article and the dispositions
thereof. In addition, the Traffic Compliance Officer shall make certified reports to the
Secretary of State pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/6-306.5, as now or hereafter amended.
Section 18-807 Respondent’s Options.
a. Prior to the 21st day after issuance of the violation notice, a person on whom a parking or
compliance violation notice has been served has the following options:
1. pay the indicated fine; or
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
33 REVISED 07/01/13
2. submit the materials set forth in this Article to obtain an adjudication by mail; or
3. request an administrative hearing as set forth in this Article to contest the charged
violation.
A response by mail shall be deemed timely if postmarked within 21 days of the issuance
of the violation notice. If none of these options is selected, the Respondent will be deemed
to have waived his/her rights to exercise any of these options.
b. If the respondent submits documentary evidence to obtain adjudication by mail pursuant
to this Article, the Traffic Compliance Officer shall send the respondent a copy of the
determination in accordance with this Article.
c. If the respondent requests an administrative hearing to contest the cited violations pursuant
to this Article, the Traffic Compliance Officer shall notify the respondent in writing of the
location and time available for a hearing in accordance with this Article.
Section 18-808 Second Notice of Violation. Upon the failure of the registered owner of the cited
vehicle to pay the appropriate fine and/or penalty prior to the 21st day, or request an adjudication
by mail, or request a hearing, the Traffic Compliance Officer shall send out a second notice of
violation which shall contain the following:
a. Date and location of violation cited in the violation notice;
b. Particular standing, parking or compliance regulation violated;
c. Vehicle make and state registration;
d. Fine and penalty that may be assessed for late payment;
Ord. # 13- 033)
e. Availability of an administrative hearing at which the alleged violation may be contested
on its merits;
f. A statement that failure to either pay the fine and any applicable penalty or appear at a
subsequent hearing on its merits on the date and at the time and place specified will result
in a determination of liability in the amount of the fine and penalty indicated; and
g. A statement that upon the occurrence of a determination of liability, and the exhaustion of,
or the failure to exhaust, available administrative and judicial procedures for review, any
unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the Village.
Section 18-809 Grounds for Adjudication by Mail or Administrative Hearing. A person
charged with a parking or compliance violation as set forth in this Article may contest the charge
through adjudication by mail or at any administrative hearing, limited to one or more of the
following grounds with appropriate evidence to support that:
a. The respondent was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle at the time of violation;
b. The cited vehicle or its State registration plates were stolen at the time the violation
occurred;
TRAFFIC
34 REVISED 02/15/10
c. The facts alleged in the parking or compliance violation notice are inconsistent or do not
support a finding that the specified ordinance was violated; and
d. The illegal condition described in the compliance violation did not exist at the time the
notice was issued.
e. In addition to the above- listed grounds, at a hearing, the hearing officer may determine that
there were other grounds sufficient to disprove liability.
Section 18-810 Adjudication by Mail – Procedure.
a. Administrative hearings to review materials submitted for the adjudication by mail of
parking and compliance violations cited pursuant to this Article shall be conducted in
accordance with this Article.
b. The respondent may contest a parking or compliance violation, based on one or more of
the grounds provided in this Article, by mailing to the Police Department the following
materials and information: the notice of violation, the full name, address and telephone
number( s) of the respondent; the make, model and year of the vehicle; any documentary
evidence that rebuts the charge; and a written statement signed by the respondent setting
forth facts relevant to establishing a defense to the charge in accordance with Section 18-
809, Grounds for Adjudication by Mail or Administrative Hearing. A photocopy of any
documentary evidence submitted by any party shall be accepted as the equivalent of the
original document.
c. No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence;
provided, however, that a parking or compliance violation notice, or a copy thereof, issued
in accordance with this Article shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts
specified therein.
d. Upon review of the materials submitted in accordance with this Section, the hearing officer
shall enter a determination of no liability or of liability and, if liability is found, the amount
of the fine. Upon issuance, such determination shall constitute a final determination for
purposes of judicial review under the Administrative Review Law of Illinois.
Section 18-811 Administrative Hearings – Procedures.
a. Administrative hearings for the adjudication of parking and compliance violations issued
pursuant to this Article shall be conducted in accordance with this Article.
b. Respondents who have failed to request a hearing after a second violation notice has been
issued shall be placed on a hearing docket containing all individuals who have failed to
respond to notices. In the event the respondent appears at the date and time of this hearing,
the hearing officer may, but is not required to, conduct a hearing at that date and time. If
the hearing officer has time after the regularly scheduled hearing to conduct the hearing,
he may do so. In the event there is no time to conduct a hearing, a hearing shall be
scheduled at a regularly scheduled hearing date in the future.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
35 REVISED 02/15/10
c. The respondent may appear pro se or, at his own expense, by an attorney. An attorney who
appears on behalf of any person shall file with the hearing officer a written appearance on
a form provided by the Village for such purpose.
d. The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply in the conduct of the hearing.
e. All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation, which shall be administered by the
hearing officer. The hearing officer may issue subpoenas to secure the attendance and
testimony of witnesses and the production of relevant documents; provided, however, that
a respondent who appears by an attorney shall not be compelled to attend the hearing and
may submit his testimony, if any, by affidavit. In addition, witnesses who have not been
subpoenaed to attend the hearing may submit their testimony, if any, by affidavit.
f. No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance of the evidence;
provided, however, that a parking or compliance violation notice or a copy thereof, issued
and signed in accordance with this Article shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness
of the facts specified therein.
g. The hearing officer may, on a showing of good cause, grant one continuance to a date
certain.
h. The Village shall cause a record to be made of each hearing, and recording devices may be
used for such purposes.
Section 18-812 Hearing – Determination of Liability – Petition to Set Aside.
a. Upon conclusion of a hearing under this Article, the hearing officer shall issue a
determination of no liability or of liability in the amount of the fine for the relevant
violation as provided in this Article.
b. If a person fails to respond to the violation notice and the second notice of violation, or has
requested an administrative hearing and fails to appear, a determination of liability shall be
entered against the respondent pursuant to this Article. Such determination shall become
final for purposes of judicial review under the Administrative Review Law of Illinois upon
the denial or the expiration of the time in which to file a timely petition to set aside the
determination as provided in this Chapter.
c. Within 21 days from the issuance of a determination of liability pursuant to this Article,
the person against whom the determination was entered may submit a written request to
the Traffic Compliance Officer to set aside the determination, provided, however, the
grounds for the petition shall be limited to:
1. the person was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date the parking
violation notice was first issued;
2. the person already paid the fine or penalty for the parking violation in question; or
3. there was an excusable failure, based upon criteria established by the hearing
officer, to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. The Traffic Compliance
Officer shall set a hearing date and provide written notice of that date to the
petitioner.
TRAFFIC
36 REVISED 02/15/10
Section 18-813 Final Determination. A final determination of violation liability shall occur
following failure to pay the fine and/or penalty after a hearing officer’ s determination of violation
liability, and the exhaustion of or failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures,
including denial of a timely petition to set aside or failing to file the set aside petition within 21
days of the determination.
Section 18-814 Notice of Final Determination.
a. If any fine or penalty is owing and unpaid after a determination of liability under this
Article has become final, and the respondent has exhausted or failed to exhaust judicial
procedures for review, the Traffic Compliance Officer shall cause a Notice of Final
Determination of Liability to be sent to the respondent in accordance with this Article.
b. Any fine and penalty, if applicable, remaining unpaid after the notice of final determination
of liability is sent, shall constitute a debt due and owing the Village which may be
enforced in any legal manner consistent with 625 ILCS 5/11- 208.3, as now or hereafter
amended. Failure of the respondent to pay such fine or penalty may result in:
1. The immobilization of the person’ s vehicle for failure to pay fines or penalties for
five or more parking or compliance violations; and/or
2. The suspension of the person’ s driver’ s license for failure to pay fines or penalties
for ten or more parking violations.
Section 18-815 Lessor of Vehicle Not Liable for Violation – When.
a. In accordance with Section 11-1306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, no person who is the
lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be liable for a violation of
any standing or parking regulation of this Article involving such vehicle during the period
of the lease if, upon receipt of a notice of violation sent within 120 days of the violation
that person shall, within 60 days thereafter, provide to the Traffic Compliance Officer the
name and address of the lessee.
b. Upon receipt of a lessor’ s notification of the name and address of the lessee provided
pursuant to Section 11-1305 or 11-1306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, the Traffic
Compliance Officer shall cause a notice of violation to be sent to the lessee as provided for
in this Article.
Ord. #10-006)
Article IX Vehicle Immobilization Program
Section 18-901 Vehicle Immobilization Program.
a. The Police Chief or designee is hereby authorized to direct and supervise a program of
vehicle immobilization for the purpose of enforcing the parking ordinances set forth in
Chapter 18, Article II, Parking, of the Arlington Heights Municipal Code. The program of
vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle located on the
public way or any Village- owned property by placement of a restraint in such a manner as
to prevent its operation.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
37 REVISED 02/15/10
b. Definitions. For purposes of this Article, the following words and phrases have the
following meanings:
1. Owner. The registered or legal owner or person who is otherwise entitled to
possession of the motor vehicle.
2. Police Immobilized Vehicle (Wheel-Lock). A vehicle located on a public way at a
time or in such a manner as to require police intervention pursuant to this Article.
c. When the registered owner of a vehicle has accumulated five or more citations of parking
violation liability, in any combination, which are each at least 120 days past the date of the
violation, for which the fines and applicable penalties, if applicable, have not been paid in
full, the Police Chief or designee shall cause a notice prior to vehicle immobilization to be
sent, in accordance with Section 18-902, Pre- Immobilization Notice, of this Article.
d. The owner of an immobilized vehicle or other authorized person may secure the release of
the vehicle by paying the immobilization, towing and storage fees provided in subsection
g) of this Section, and all fines and penalties remaining due on each final determination of
liability issued to such person.
e. All motor vehicles towed pursuant to this Article shall be impounded in locations
determined by the Police Chief.
f. The owner of a vehicle covered by this Article shall have the right to an administrative
hearing to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing was erroneous.
Hearings requested pursuant to this Article shall be conducted by a hearing officer upon
receipt of a written request for a hearing. Hearing officers shall be appointed by the Village
to conduct any of the administrative hearings provided for in this Article. The hearing
officers shall have the authority to require the presence of Village personnel or witnesses
at such hearing. Any determination of the hearing officer regarding the validity of any
action pursuant to this Article shall be a final determination for the purpose of judicial
review under the Administrative Review Law of Illinois upon issuance.
g. The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall be subject to a fee of $ 125 for such
immobilization. The owner will also be liable to the private towing company for all towing
charges and storage fees.
h. It shall be unlawful to remove or damage the immobilizing device or to relocate or tow any
vehicle restrained by an immobilization device without the prior approval of the Village.
Any person who violates this Section shall be subject to a penalty of $500 for each such
violation.
Section 18-902 Pre-Immobilization Notice. Upon accumulation of five or more outstanding or
otherwise unsettled parking violation notices and/ or Village vehicle license violation notices, a
pre-immobilization notice shall be sent by regular mail to the owner of such vehicle or placed on
the owner' s vehicle when the owner cannot be reached by mail.
The notice shall state the name and address of the registered owner, the state registration number
of the vehicle or vehicles registered to such owner, and the serial numbers of parking violation
notices which have resulted in final determination of liability for which fines and/ or penalties
remain unpaid. Failure to pay the fines and penalties owed within 21 days from the date of the
notice will result in the inclusion of the state registration number of the vehicle or vehicles of such
TRAFFIC
38 REVISED 02/15/10
owner on an immobilization list.
Section 18-903 Pre- Immobilization Review. A person may challenge the validity of the preimmobilization
notice by presenting to the Police Department written documentation of any of the
following:
a. That all fines and penalties for the violations cited in the notice have been paid in full; or
b. That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more final determinations of parking
violation liability which were unpaid at the time the notice of impending vehicle
immobilization was issued.
Section 18-904 Post-Immobilization Notice. Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a postimmobilization
notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. The notice shall warn
that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage.
The notice shall also state that the unauthorized removal of or damage to the immobilizing restraint
is a violation of Section 18-901h, Vehicle Immobilization Program. The notice shall also provide
information specifying how release of the immobilizing restraint may be had, and how the
registered owner may obtain a post-immobilization hearing. If the restraint has not been released
within 24 hours of its placement, the restraint shall be released and the vehicle towed and
impounded.
Section 18-905 Post-Immobilization Review. A person may challenge the validity of the vehicle
immobilization by presenting to the Police Department written documentation of any of the
following:
a. That all fines and penalties for the violations cited in the notice have been paid in full; or
b. That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more final determinations of parking
violation liability which were unpaid at the time the notice of impending vehicle
immobilization was issued.
Section 18-906 Post- Tow Notice. Whenever a vehicle is towed following immobilization in
accordance with this Article, the Police Department shall provide to the owner of the vehicle the
notice described in this Section no later than one business day after the day of the tow, except that
when a motor vehicle is towed after 3:00 P.M. on a Friday, Saturday, Sunday or holiday, as that
term is defined in Section 18-101d, Definition of Words and Phrases- Holidays, or the day before
a holiday, the notice described herein shall be provided no later than the second business day after
the tow.
a. Within ten days after a vehicle has been towed and impounded, a notice of impoundment
shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the registered
owner as listed with the Secretary of State.
b. The post- tow notice shall include the following information:
1. The description of the motor vehicle including year, make, model, registration and
vehicle identification number ( VIN);
2. The present location of the motor vehicle;
3. The basis for the removal of the vehicle;
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
39 REVISED 02/15/10
4. The right of the owner to a hearing as set forth in Section 18-907, Post Tow
Hearings, of this Article;
5. The consequences of the failure to request a hearing;
6. The consequences of a failure to reclaim the motor vehicle, including a statement
that if the vehicle is not claimed within 30 days from the date of the post- tow notice,
the vehicle may be sold or otherwise disposed of in accordance with Section 4-208
of the Illinois Vehicle Code;
7. A deadline date seven calendar days from the date of notice, by which the owner
must respond to the post- tow notice.
b. The notice required in this Section shall, at the discretion of the Police Department, be
given by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal delivery. The date of
personal delivery or the date of mailing of the certified letter shall be the date of providing
notice.
c. A notice containing the requirements set forth above shall be posted at the Arlington
Heights police station and at all tow impound areas.
d. If the registered or legal owner or person who is otherwise entitled to possession of a motor
vehicle does not request a hearing within seven days of the mailing of the post- tow notice,
the right to a post- tow hearing shall be forfeited. The registered or legal owner or person
who is otherwise entitled to possession of a motor vehicle must pay the total cost of the
tow and any storage incurred.
Section 18-907 Post- Tow Hearings.
a. The owner of a vehicle towed following wheel lock immobilization pursuant to this Article
shall be provided the opportunity for a post- tow hearing only for the limited purpose of
challenging the validity of the tow and any tow or storage charges. Aperson may challenge
the validity of the tow by filing a written request for a hearing with the Police Department.
This hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicate, any citation issued relative to any
towed vehicle.
b. Hearings shall take place as follows:
1. In those instances where the vehicle has been released upon the deposit of a cash
bond in an amount equal to the tow and storage charge, the hearing shall take place
within seven days after the posting of cash bond.
2. In those instances where the vehicle remains impounded, the hearing shall take
place at the option of the owner, either within seven days after receipt of a written
request or within 14 days for good cause shown by the owner of the motor vehicle.
c. The Hearing Officer shall review all evidence presented and make a finding as to whether
there was lawful authority for the tow and storage of the vehicle. The Village must
establish its authority by a preponderance of the evidence. The Village shall establish a
prima facie case upon a showing of the documents related to the tow, i.e., the police
citation( s), police order or the police report and/ or the tow report. The Police Chief shall
TRAFFIC
40 REVISED 02/15/10
establish procedures to authenticate and present the above documents at an administrative
post-tow hearing.
d. Documentary evidence which disproves liability shall be based on the following grounds:
1. That all fines and penalties for the violations cited in the notice have been paid in
full; or
2. That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more final determinations of
parking violation liability which were unpaid at the time the notice of impending
vehicle immobilization was issued. Such notice shall indicate that the owner' s
vehicle is subject to being immobilized unless the owner of said vehicle, within 30
days of the date of notice: or
3. A sufficient explanation so that the hearing officer finds it disproves liability.
e. The Hearing Officer shall advise the owner and the Village of the findings at the conclusion
of the hearing:
1. If the tow and storage is determined to have been in accordance with this Article,
the owner shall be so informed and further advised of the amount owed, if any, for
tow and storage;
2. If the tow and storage is determined to not be in accordance with this Article, the
Hearing Officer shall so inform the owner and:
a) If the vehicle is impounded at the time of hearing, the Hearing Officer shall
order the vehicle to be immediately released;
b) If the vehicle has been released, the Hearing Officer shall order that a refund
of the cash bond be made to the owner within five business days.
3. If the owner has requested a continuance, the Hearing Officer may, upon a showing
of good cause, grant a continuance for no greater than 14 days.
f. The registered or legal owner or person who is otherwise entitled to possession of a motor
vehicle does not claim and take possession of said motor vehicle within 15 days after the
date of the post-tow hearing, the motor vehicle shall be considered abandoned and shall be
disposed of pursuant to applicable State statutes.
Section 18-908 Release of Vehicle. The owner of an immobilized vehicle, or other authorized
person, shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle upon payment of any of the following,
such payment to be only in cash or by check:
a. Depositing with the Village, as collateral for his or her appearance at the administrative
hearing to answer for each violation, 50% of the total fines and penalties for all violations
for which there are outstanding or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices and/ or
Village vehicle license violations; or
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
41 REVISED 02/15/10
b. Depositing with the Village the amount of the fine or penalty for each violation for which
there is an outstanding or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices and/or Village
vehicle license violations; and
c. The payment of the immobilized vehicle fees as required by Section 18-901g and h,
Vehicle Immobilization Program, of this Article.

19-3 REVISED 03/07/16
Article I Garbage and Refuse
Ord. #11-006, #12-007, # 16-004)
Section 19-101 Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words or terms, for
the purposes of this Article, shall have the meanings indicated in this Section.
a. Approved Solid Waste Container. Garbage carts, landscape waste carts, recycling carts and
recycling bins, as provided by the Village’ s solid waste contractor.
b. Compost. Amixture of decayed or decaying organic matter used to fertilize soil. Compost is
made by gathering plant material, such as leaves, grass clippings, and vegetable peels, into a
pile or bin and letting it decompose as a result of the action of aerobic bacteria, fungi, and
other organisms.
c. Compost Container. Aprefabricated bin, tumbler, or structure made of fencing or blocks no
larger than 5 feet x 5 feet x 5 feet.
d. Disposable Waste Container. Any bag, box or other container of sufficient strength and
durability to withstand handling until its contents are put into the hopper of the Contractor’ s
vehicle for removal.
e. Dwelling Unit. Any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single
habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping,
cooking and eating.
f. Family Unit. One or more persons living together in a dwelling and maintaining a common
household.
g. Garbage. Any rejected or waste, household food, offal, swill or carrion and every
accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter that attends the preparation, use, cooking
and dealing in, or storage of meats, fish, fowl, fruits or vegetables and any other matter of
any nature, which are subject to decay, putrefaction and the generation of noxious or
offensive gases or odor, or which during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding
material for flies or other germ-carrying insects.
h. Landscape Waste. All accumulation of grass, shrubbery cuttings, leaves, tree limbs or trunks
less than six inches in diameter, and other materials accumulated as a result of the care of
lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees.
i. Multi-family Properties. Any dwelling containing more than three dwelling units.
j. Owner. The person, corporation, partnership or other entity who owns the multi-family
property or the designated agent or association responsible for refuse collection.
k. Person. Any natural person, partnership, trust, corporation or association, or any
governmental agency or municipal or quasi municipal corporation. Whenever used with
respect to any penalty, the term "person" as applied to partnerships or associations shall mean
HEALTH AND SANITATION
19-4 REVISED 02/20/12
the partners or members thereof, and as applied to trusts or corporations shall mean the
trustees or officers thereof.
l. Premises. Any house, residence, building, flat, apartment, room, dwelling place or place of
abode.
m. Recyclables or Recyclable Materials. Newspaper, aluminum and steel food and beverage
cans, glass containers, and any other materials designated or approved by the Village for
recycling by a licensed scavenger operating within the Village.
n. Recycling. The collection and processing of recyclables in a manner that enables further use
of such materials in the manufacturing of new, reusable or reconstituted products. Recycling
does not include landfilling or incineration.
o. Recycling Program. A waste recovery program which provides for collection, separation,
and composting of solid waste and processing of collected materials into new products.
p. Refuse. All garbage, ashes, discarded household litter, scraps, junk and waste, furniture,
furnishings, carpet and paddings, mattresses, laundry tubs, bathtubs, kitchen sinks, plumbing
fixtures, small appliances, small auto parts, manure, dead animals or parts thereof, tree limbs,
trunks and roots six inches or greater in diameter, building material, sod, dirt, concrete,
asphalt and other waste not separated at the source and disposed of through a recycling
program.
q. Residential Solid Waste Contractor. The contractor with whom the Village has contracted
for the removal of garbage, refuse, recyclable material, landscape waste and white goods in
accordance with the Village’ s residential solid waste collection and removal program.
r. Reusable Refuse Container. A container of galvanized iron or non-corrodible metal or
plastic, durable and leak-proof, of the type commonly sold as a garbage can, of a suitable
gauge and construction to insure durability, with suitable handles on both the can and the lid.
Refuse containers for commercial facilities and apartment houses containing four or more
family units, shall be rodent-proof, leak-proof and with fitted covers.
s. Scavenger. A licensed waste hauler responsible for collecting waste from property.
t. Sheet Composting. Spreading a thin layer of organic materials, such as leaves, over a garden
area.
u. Solid Waste. Garbage, refuse, recyclable material, landscape waste and white goods.
v. White Goods. Refrigerators, ranges, water heaters, freezers, air conditioners, humidifiers and
other similar domestic and commercial large appliances.
Section 19-102 Administration. The Village Manager or designee shall supervise all matters
relating to or affecting the accumulation, collection, removal or disposal of solid waste. All solid
waste containers shall be subject to inspection and approval by the Village Manager. The Village
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
5 REVISED 02/21/11
Manager is authorized to cause all solid waste to be collected regularly and systematically in
accordance with the Village’ s current contract for collection of solid waste.
Section 19-103 Responsibilities of Owners and Occupants.
a. No person, except at construction sites, shall permit any solid waste to accumulate on his or
her premises, except in covered reusable refuse containers.
b. The owner of a multiple dwelling containing two or more family units or the owner of a
commercial or industrial establishment containing one or more businesses:
1. Shall provide approved type solid waste storage and collection facilities and disposal
services for all occupants whether the occupants be the owner or tenants;
2. Shall not permit any solid waste to accumulate which is not contained in an approved
solid waste storage and refuse collection facility and shall not allow litter in
alleyways, parking lots, or other outdoor areas of the property.
c. Written agreements between owner and occupants shall not relieve the owner of final
responsibility for proper solid waste storage, disposal or collection facilities.
d. Solid waste storage sites for newly constructed or substantially remodeled multi-family
residential, commercial or industrial establishments shall meet the following criteria:
1. Container Site:
a. Area shall be of a sufficient size to easily accommodate the container;
b. The surface shall be paved, curbed and graded to the front to prevent
accumulation of liquid;
c. Visual screening of the site shall be provided;
2. Access to Container:
a. Sufficient space to accommodate the turning requirements of the scavenger
truck shall be provided;
b. Parking, fences, plantings, etc., shall be located so as to create no obstacles to
service vehicles.
e. The Director of Health Services shall be responsible for implementation of all regulations
pertaining to refuse storage and collection.
Ord. #11-006)
Section 19-104 Recycling Programs. Recyclable materials separated from refuse and destined to be
reused or recycled, and which are not discarded with refuse, are considered to be the property of the
owner and may be disposed of through a recycling program rather than a refuse disposal
HEALTH AND SANITATION
6 REVISED 02/21/11
system. Recycling operations must be conducted in such a way as to avoid fire and sanitation
hazards. Storage and handling of waste materials must conform to the applicable provisions of the
Life Safety Code of the National Fire Protection Association and the health and sanitation
requirements of this Code.
Recyclable materials from which refuse is not separated must be disposed of through the facilities of
a solid waste contractor. It shall be unlawful for persons other than the owner or the contractor to
remove recyclable materials from the recycling bins or recycling carts.
Section 19-105 Refuse Containers Required; Placing and Maintenance. Every person in
possession of any premises in the Village where persons reside shall provide for each occupied
family unit, sufficient reusable refuse containers for accumulation of normal refuse. Every person in
possession of any premises shall cause to be deposited in the refuse containers all refuse produced in,
or brought into the premises, after it is produced.
All reusable refuse containers shall be as previously defined, and no other type of container shall be
acceptable: unsanitary, leaking or defective receptacles or receptacles without covers shall be
cleaned, repaired or replaced by the owner or occupant at their expense, as directed by the Village
Manager or the Director of Health Services, or their respective representatives. All containers shall
be cleaned as often as is necessary to maintain them in a sanitary condition.
Section 19-106 Content of Containers. It shall be the duty of every person in possession of any
premises to cause all garbage brought on or produced on the premises to be thoroughly drained of all
surplus liquid, securely wrapped in paper or packed in a covered box or carton of the dimensions that
will permit its free passage into and out of the refuse container and finally deposited, after wrapping,
in a refuse container. The solid waste contractor’ s crews will not service refuse containers to which
garbage is frozen through failure to observe these regulations or containers which are other than as
specified in this Article. All solid waste shall be securely wrapped, bound or contained in a manner
that will prevent scattering by the wind or by animals.
Ord. #11-006)
Section 19-107 Location of Solid Waste Containers. It shall be unlawful for any person to place
any reusable solid waste container at the curb or within the alley, street or walkway (except where
there is no parkway between the walkway and the street), unless it is the approved solid waste
containers supplied by the Village’ s solid waste contractor. Reusable refuse containers and approved
solid waste containers shall be permitted only in side or rear yards for temporary storage of waste and
shall be located entirely within the lot line. No single refuse container and its contents shall exceed
50 pounds for residents who have back door collection.
Ord. #11-006)
Section 19-108 Solid Waste to be Placed at the Curb. All residential solid waste, whether at the
curb or behind the front line of the residence, is governed by the following requirements:
a. Items to be placed at the curb include refuse bags, landscape waste bags, approved solid
waste containers, brush or branches securely tied in five-foot bundles, and other items placed
in disposable containers weighing not more than 50 pounds each; also, large items such as
white goods, household furniture and other items which can be handled by two people.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
7 REVISED 07/06/99
Ord. #99-047)
b. Items shall be placed at the curb by the resident on the day of collection prior to 7:00 a.m.
Items shall not be placed at the curb prior to 7:00 p.m. the day preceding collection during
the months of April through October or prior to 4:00 p.m. the day preceding collection during
the months of November through March.
Ord. #99-045)
c. Empty approved solid waste containers shall be removed from the curb, by the resident, not
later than 8:00 a.m. the day after collection.
d. Items eligible to be placed at the curb shall be placed adjacent to the curb so that it can be
easily loaded into a truck in the street.
Section 19-109 Collection and Disposal. At residences of less than four family units, all solid
waste shall be disposed of by the Village’ s solid waste contractor, and shall not be collected or
disposed of in any other manner.
Section 19-110 Solid Waste Collection Fees. Fees to be charged by the Village’s solid waste
contractor shall be in accordance with the Village’s current contract for solid waste collection, which
is available at the Village Clerk’s office.
Section 19-111 No Dumping or Burying of Solid Waste. No solid waste shall be burned, dumped
or buried within the Village limits.
Section 19-112 Disposal of Solid Waste Other than by Collection.
a. Solid waste may not be burned at any time within the Village except when authorized byand
in compliance with all fire prevention regulations of this Code.
b. Garbage may be disposed of within the building where it is accumulated by grinding or by
shredding, and disposing of it through pipes leading through a catch basin to a public sanitary
sewer, provided that all garbage so disposed of in the pipes is ground or shredded enough to
allow all particles to be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in the
sewers into which same is deposited, with no particle greater than ½ inch in any dimension
and all grinders used for disposal of wastes must be approved bythe Director of Building and
licensed as required by Article V of this Chapter.
Section 19-113 Licensing Requirements. One contractor will service single-family residences and
multiple-family residences of three or less units. The number of contractors servicing commercial
facilities and multiple family residences of four or more units shall be governed byChapter 14 of this
Code.
Section 19-114 Transportation Sanitation Requirements. No person shall transport solid waste
or cause it to be transported, over the streets or other public ways in the Village unless the solid
waste being transported is entirely and securely covered. Garbage shall not be transported over or
along the streets of the Village or other public property except in a leak-proof compaction type body
referred to as a " packer type" refuse body, approved by the Village Manager. The
HEALTH AND SANITATION
8
equipment shall not be permitted to remain parked anywhere in the Village limits when not in use,
but may be stored or kept when not in use in a tightly constructed and closed building or shed,
provided the building or structure shall conform with the requirements of the Zoning provisions of
this Code. Any solid waste that may have been spilled by the hauler on private premises, parkways,
streets, alleys or other public places shall be immediately cleaned up in a neat and sanitary manner.
Solid waste disposal contractors shall replace, at their own expense, any containers which may be
damaged by the carelessness of their employees.
Section 19-115 Residential Service Required. Every person in possession of any premises in the
Village, except commercial and industrial establishments and all apartments or other buildings with
four or more family units, shall, except as otherwise provided, be required to have solid waste
collected and disposed of regularly by the solid waste disposal contractor employed by the Village.
The occupancy of any premises for residential purposes shall be prima facie evidence that solid
waste is being produced and accumulated on the premises, and it shall be the duty of the designated
representative of the Village to inspect the premises and cause to be removed any and all solid waste
found, unless the premises are equipped with approved disposal facilities. Any expense to the
Village for solid waste removal shall be reimbursed by the person whose name is listed on the water
or sewer account.
All charges for solid waste disposal service shall be billed by the Village’s disposal contractor to and
be paid by the person in whose name the Village water or sewer account then appears, or the person
at the head of the family unit that receives service, and the Contractor shall assume any and all
delinquent accounts. The charges for services shall be billed and collected by the Contractor and the
Contractor shall keep an accurate record of all the family units served, including the address. The
charges may be billed in advance, payable on or before the due date. Upon advance notice that solid
waste service paid for in advance will not be required or has not been required because a residence is
unoccupied, the Contractor shall refund or adjust on a monthly pro rata basis an amount equal to the
service paid for, but not received or not to be received, provided no refunds will be allowed for
discontinuance of service for less than 30 days.
Section 19-116 Service to Industry, Business, Etc. Apartments and other buildings containing
four or more family units and commercial and industrial establishments shall have their solid waste
removed by a solid waste disposal contractor who is licensed to operate in the Village.
Section 19-117 Solid Waste from Building Contractors' Operations. Solid waste accumulated
from the operation of lot cleaning or clearing or caused by building, rebuilding or otherwise altering
a building or structure shall be removed by the person or building contractor performing the work,
except that the contractor may employ a solid waste contractor licensed under the provisions of
Chapter 14 of this Code. The contractor shall only remove solid waste generated as a result of repair
or construction. This contractor need not be the Village’s disposal contractor.
Section 19-118 Hours of Collection.
a. Residential. Collection of all solid waste in residential areas shall be conducted between the
hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
9
b. Commercial. Commercial customers may be serviced by solid waste collectors between the
hours of 4:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., except in areas adjacent to residentially zoned property, in
which case refuse shall be collected between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
Section 19-119 Multi-Family Recycling Programs Required.
a. All owners of multi-family properties shall make recycling services available to all residents
residing in the property. This service will be a joint responsibility of the owner and the
scavenger for the multi-family property.
b. Participation by the individual multi-family households will not be mandatory. In addition,
there shall be no prescribed level of participation. The owners of multi-family properties
must develop and implement a recycling plan with adequate procedures and management in
order to stimulate participation.
Section 19-120 Plan Requirements and Timetables. All multi-family properties shall submit to
the Village an acceptable plan for the establishment and the administration of a recycling program
from multi-family property residents. The recycling plan shall be reviewed by the Village to
determine compliance with this Article. The Village shall notify all parties whether plans are
acceptable or unacceptable. Unacceptable plans must be revised and resubmitted to the Village
within 15 days of the date of the notice that the plan is unacceptable. Recycling services must begin
within 60 days of plan approval. The plan shall include, at a minimum, but is not limited to,
specifics concerning:
a. Siting and design of collection areas which must be convenient to residents and adequate in
number; a map of properties with exterior recycling areas showing buildings, parking areas,
lawn areas, sidewalks, and recycling areas; count of all parking spaces before and after
implementation of recycling;
b. Collection process;
c. Provision and type of containers; collection areas large enough to accommodate the recycling
containers; enlarged enclosures in the same style and color as the original enclosure;
information about number and size of recycling containers, and number of one, two, and
three bedroom units; provision of photos or advertising literature about recycling containers,
if available;
d. Data collection and reporting; data about volume of refuse generated prior to the recycling
program;
e. Method of administration;
f. Educational campaign and materials to inform residents about the availability of recycling;
the materials shall be submitted to the Village for review and approval;
g. Identification and information about the subcontractor, if applicable.
HEALTH AND SANITATION
10 REVISED 05/06/02
Alteration to approved site plans for multi-family properties for garbage/recycling areas shall be
reviewed by the appropriate Village departments for approval of all changes. Consideration for
approval shall include impacts upon required parking, landscaping, handicapped parking spaces and
other site planning issues. Site plan changes deemed to be minor in nature may be approved
administratively. Modifications that reduce the required parking or landscaping shall require
amendments through the appropriate public hearing process.
If the plan is prepared by the waste contractor, the property owner or official in charge must indicate
concurrence with the plan by signing the plan.
The Village may permit a multi-family property to participate in the Village single-family curbside
recycling program for a fee to be specified by the Village if the Village determines the plan is a
desirable method of providing multi-family recycling services to the property's residents.
Section 19-121 Recycling Collection; Specific Requirements.
a. Recycling collection areas shall be adequate in number and shall be conveniently located and
maintained within common areas in or near the buildings.
b. The area shall consist of separate containers of sufficient number and size for the purposes of
temporary storage of recyclables. Containers shall be of durable material capable of
withstanding heavy wear and tear.
c. Exterior recycling collection areas shall conform with Code requirements for facilities for the
collection and storage of refuse.
d. The owner shall maintain all recycling areas, including the containers, in a clean and sanitary
manner.
e. The owner shall offer collection of a minimum of these six materials ( no substitutions
permitted):
1. newspaper;
2. glass (clear, green and brown);
3. steel cans (also known as bi-metal or tin cans);
4. aluminum cans;
5. PET (type 1) plastic containers; and
6. HDPE (Type 2) plastic containers.
Ord. #02-035)
f. Collection of recyclables shall be by some version of source separation and separate
collection containers shall be employed. The collection of recyclables by the method of
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
11
mixed solid waste sorting or co-collection known as the "bluebag method," may be allowed
only when deemed permissible by the Health Department due to unique circumstances.
g. The minimum gallon amount of recycling capacity ( total base capacity) an owner shall
provide weekly for each multi-family property shall be based on the following formula:
7 gallons x number of studio and 1 bedroom units) + ( 8 gallons x
number of 2 bedroom units) + (9 gallons x number of 3 bedroom or
more units) = total base capacity
The weekly base capacity may be met by a combination of container sizes and number of
pick-ups, such as containers totaling half the base capacity picked up twice aweek. Capacity
per building may be shifted within the multi-family property, if necessary, so long as the total
required capacity is met.
h. The licensed scavenger shall be responsible for furnishing, maintaining and replacing all
recycling collection equipment which is deemed necessary in the recycling program. The
contractor shall be responsible for the collection, intermediate storage or transfer,
transportation, and sale of recyclables to a processor, broker or market destined for reuse of
the materials.
Section 19-122 Notice.
a. Owners must provide all residents with written notice about the recycling program, and shall
use their best efforts to gain and maintain participation in the program. This notice shall be
in the form, have the content and be distributed in a manner approved by the Village.
b. In addition to providing this notice to each dwelling unit, the notice shall also be posted in
clearly visible locations in common areas. The notice shall also be kept in reserve to be
provided to new residents as they move in.
c. The owner shall also maintain signs at collection areas identifying the materials to be
collected and designating containers for the materials. Signs must be clearly visible and, if
outside, must be weatherproof.
d. Residents shall be furnished with the phone numbers of the hauler and the contact person for
the property so that questions can be answered and problems resolved.
Section 19-123 Reporting Requirements.
a. Each scavenger shall submit an annual report to both the multi-family owner(s) or designee
and the Village that contains the following information:
1. reasonable estimates, with supporting documentation, of the total weight or volume
of refuse collected from multi-family properties;
HEALTH AND SANITATION
12 REVISED 02/20/12
2. reasonable estimates, with supporting documentation, of the total weight or volume
of recyclables collected from multi-family properties.
b. Reports shall be due no later than January 30 of each year. Reports shall follow the format
prescribed by the Village.
c. The Village shall have the right to inspect and examine the scavenger's facility and records
pertaining to the collection and disposal or processing of refuse and recyclables upon request
with reasonable notice. The Village shall also have the right to require other data or
information relative to the recycling program and conduct site inspections of the multi-family
recycling facilities as deemed necessary.
d. All the reports, data, and information, once received by the Village, shall become the
property of the Village to be used, as it shall determine without obligation to any person, firm
or corporation.
Section 19-124 Continuation of ProgramRequired. The recycling program shall be maintained in
effect regardless of any change of owner or scavenger. The owner shall notify the Village within 30
days in the event of a change in their choice of scavenger. Prior approval from the Village is
required before changing a recycling plan. Properties will be subject to inspection by the Village to
ascertain whether the recycling program complies with the plan and all applicable Village
regulations.
Ord. #12-007)
Section 19-125 Compost. All compost shall be maintained using approved composting procedures
for gardening and landscaping purposes. The Arlington Heights Park District is exempt from these
requirements.
a. All compost shall be located in a compost container as permitted in this Section, unless the
sheet composting method is being utilized.
b. No more than three compost containers shall be allowed on properties of ½ acre or less.
c. Compost containers shall be located only in the side yard or rear yard. For properties of ½
acre or less, such containers must be placed a minimum of five feet from the property line or
25 feet from neighboring dwellings. For properties in excess of ½ acre, such containers must
be located a minimum of 25 feet from neighboring dwellings. Where a side lot line is
adjacent to a street, any compost container must adhere to the setback requirement for the
principal structure.
d. Items such as, but not limited to, the following organic materials are allowed in the compost
pile: soil, grass clippings, waste sod, wood chips, shredded paper, egg shells, coffee grounds,
straw, leaves, cooked and uncooked fruits and vegetables. Small amounts of activators may
be added to facilitate the process.
e. Compost shall not contain household garbage, meat or any meat product, fatty food, bones,
animal feces, diseased plants, treated wood, manure, or non-plant materials.
f. Compost shall be maintained to prevent the harboring and breeding of animals and offensive
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
13 REVISED 02/20/12
odors by frequent turning of the compost material to permit aeration.
g. Newer composting techniques or devices may be permitted if they are reviewed and
approved by the Director of Building and Health Services, with the advice of the
Environmental Commission.
Section 19-126 Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation guilty of violating any of the provisions of
this Article shall be fined not less than $50 nor more than $750 for each offense, and their license
shall be subject to revocation.
Article II Nuisances
Section 19-201 Definitions.
a. Improper Growth of Weeds or Grasses. All weeds or grasses on vacant land over 12 inches
in height from the ground and all weeds or grasses on occupied lots over eight inches in
height from the ground.
b. Inoperable Vehicle. Any motor vehicle from which the engine, wheels or other parts have
been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven
safely under its own motor power on the streets of the Village.
c. Nuisance. Any act, which the common law classifies as a nuisance, or any act declared a
nuisance by this Code, or by a Statute of the State of Illinois.
Ord. #08-034)
d. Proper Notification. Personal service, letter sent by messenger service or certified mail. If
the notice is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted
in a conspicuous place in or about the structure or property affected by such notice and a
copy sent by regular mail. No abatement action shall be taken bythe Village until seven days
after the notice is mailed and property posted.
Section 19-202 Unlawful to Cause a Nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause a
nuisance, or to permit a nuisance to continue under his or her control, or on property under his or her
control, or to fail to abate any nuisance after notification or recognition of its existence.
Section 19-203 Nuisances. Any one or more of the following shall be deemed to be and are hereby
declared nuisances:
a. Obstructing any watercourse or source of water supply in the Village;
b. Pollution of any course, pool, or source of water supply in the Village;
c. Any stagnant pool of water;
d. Any accumulation of solid waste of any kind;
e. Any solid waste of any kind buried within the Village;
HEALTH AND SANITATION
14 REVISED 09/15/08
f. Any building or structure in a condition as to be dangerous to the public in any way;
g. Any business that is offensive;
h. Any improper growth of weeds as set forth in Section 19-209;
i. Any infestation of rats and vermin;
j. Any activity or condition that attracts wild animals, including birds and insects, in a manner
or in numbers that causes damage to other property or a hazard to the public health;
k. Any inoperable vehicle, unless within a wholly enclosed building, except for vehicles on the
premises of a place of business engaged in motor vehicle wrecking or repair.
Section 19-204 Smoke and Particulate Matter. The emission of smoke and particulate matter in
the manner and quantity as to endanger or to be detrimental to the public health, safety, comfort or
welfare is declared to be a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to
knowingly permit the emission of smoke and particulate matter from any fire, chimney, engine, oil
burner or from any other source in the Village in violation of this Section.
The burning of leaves, solid waste or the maintenance of any bonfire within the corporate limits is
declared to be a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or to knowingly permit
the burning of leaves or solid waste in any manner within the corporate limits of the Village in
violation of this Section.
Section 19-205 Dust Prevention. Dust and other types of air pollution borne by the wind from
sources such as storage areas, yards, roads and the like shall be kept to a minimum by landscaping,
paving, oiling, fencing, cutting of weeds or other appropriate means.
Section 19-206 Odors. It shall be unlawful to cause or to knowingly permit the emission of
objectionable or hazardous odors in quantities so as to be readily detectable by an observer at any
point on the boundary line of any premises or beyond.
Section 19-207 Further Restrictions. Nothing in this Section shall be construed as limiting those
requirements of the zoning ordinance and other provisions of this Code, which regulate more strictly
the emission of smoke or particulate matter.
Ord. #08-034)
Section 19-208 Abatement of Nuisances - Village. If the person in control on the property on
which any nuisance is located fails to abate it within seven days after proper notification is given, the
Village Manager is authorized to cause the abatement of the nuisance in any reasonable manner,
including removal, impounding and disposal, in accordance with the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code.
However, if the nuisance poses an immediate danger to public health and safety, the Village
Manager, after consultation with representatives from the Health Department and the
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
15
Legal Department, is authorized to cause the abatement of the nuisance in any reasonable manner
without prior notice to the person in control of the property. Any reasonable expense incurred by
the Village in abating the nuisance shall be a charge against the owner, which maybe recovered in an
appropriate action at law. However, nothing in this Section shall apply to any motor vehicle that is
kept within a building when not in use, to operable historic vehicles over 25 years of age, or to motor
vehicles on the premises of a place of business engaged in the business of wrecking or junking of
motor vehicles.
In addition to all other remedies provided by law, the Village shall have a lien on the lot or plot of
real estate on which the nuisance was found, for the reasonable cost of the abatement of the nuisance.
The lien shall be superior to all other liens and encumbrances except tax liens. Within 60 days after
the cost is incurred, the Village shall cause to be filed a notice of lien in the Office of the Recorder or
Registrar of Titles of Cook County. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: (1) a
description of the real estate sufficient for identification; (2) the amount of money representing the
cost and expense incurred or payable for each service; and (3) the date or dates when the cost and
expense were incurred by the Village.

In cases in which a property owner is in violation of Section 19-209, Growth or Accumulation –

the property owner shall be charged a fee of $50 plus costs.
Section 19-209 Growth or Accumulation - Lots. It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or
occupant, or his or her agent, servant, representative or employee, having charge or control of any lot
within the Village of Arlington Heights, to permit or maintain on any lot, including the area located
between the property line and the middle of the alley adjacent to the property, and the area located
between the property line and the curb, and the area located ten feet outside the property line where
there is no curb, any improper growth of weeds or grasses.

Title 35 Environmental Protection, Subtitle H, Noise, Chapter I, Pollution Control Board, datedMay

Article III Drugs and Narcotics
Section 19-301 Definitions. Unless otherwise expressly stated, for the purposes of this Article, the
Village expressly adopts the definitions contained in 720 ILCS 570/102, as now or hereafter
amended.
Section 19-302 Unlawful to Possess. It is unlawful for any person to manufacture, possess, have
under his or her control, sell, prescribe, administer, dispense or compound any narcotic drug, except
as authorized in this Article. No person shall unlawfully use, or be under the influence of, narcotic
drugs.
Section 19-303 Place of Use. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a building or part
thereof, or place of any description whatsoever, owned by or under his or her control to be used for
manufacture, preparation, sale, storage, smoking or use of any narcotic drug, except as provided in
this Article.
HEALTH AND SANITATION
16
Section 19-304 Distribution by a Licensed Physician, Dentist or Veterinary Surgeon. Narcotic
drugs may be dispensed or distributed to a patient by a licensed physician, dentist or veterinary
surgeon in the course of his or her professional practice only; a physician, dentist or veterinary
surgeon may possess the same for these purposes only.
Section 19-305 Distribution by a Licensed Pharmacist. Narcotic drugs may be dispensed or
distributed by a licensed pharmacist to a patient pursuant to a written prescription issued by any
licensed physician, dentist or veterinary surgeon, and the licensed pharmacist may possess the same
for these purposes only.
Section 19-306 Records. All instances of professional distribution bylicensed physicians, dentists,
veterinary surgeons and pharmacists, shall be recorded in suitable form filed and preserved in a
manner so as to be readily accessible for inspection by any law enforcement officers of the Village.
Section 19-307 Possession by Patients. Any patient may possess and use narcotic drugs dispensed
or distributed to him or her under the provisions of this Article, and the possession and use must be
in accordance with the terms of the prescription and the prescribed treatment of a licensed physician,
dentist or veterinary surgeon.
Section 19-308 Possession by a Licensed Wholesaler or Manufacturer. Narcotic drugs may be
possessed by any person who is a licensed wholesaler or manufacturer of narcotic drugs for the
purposes of wholesale, delivery, compounding, preparation and manufacture only, and the narcotic
drugs may be resold to other persons permitted by the terms of this Article to resell, dispense or
distribute them in the course of a licensed manufacture or wholesale business, a licensed professional
practice or a licensed pharmaceutical business. Alicensed wholesaler or manufacturer mayalso be a
licensed pharmacist, maydispense or distribute narcotic drugs upon written prescription provided in
this division, but shall not consume or permit to be consumed any narcotic drug except upon written
prescription as provided in this Article.
Section 19-309 Seizure and Confiscation. All of the narcotic drugs in the possession of any
person convicted of violation of this Article shall be seized by, confiscated by and forfeited to the
Chief of Police who shall make proper disposition.
Section 19-310 Exemptions from this Article. This Article shall not apply to the administering,
distributing or dispensing of any medicinal preparation that contains in one fluid ounce, or if a solid
or semi-solid preparation in one avoirdupois ounce, not more than one grain of codeine or any of its
salts; provided, that the preparation administered, distributed or dispensed shall contain some drug of
medicinal qualities in addition to those possessed by the narcotic drug alone. The preparation shall
be administered, distributed or dispensed in good faith and not for the purpose of evading this
Article. However, no person shall administer, dispense or sell, under the exemption of this Section,
any preparation included in this Section, when he or she knows, or can by reasonable diligence
ascertain, that the administering, dispensing or selling will provide the person to whom or forwhom
use the preparation is administered, dispensed or sold within any 48 consecutive hours, with more
than four grains of codeine or any of its salts.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
19-17 REVISED 07/07/14
Provisions of this Article restricting the possession or control of narcotic drugs shall not apply to
common carriers or warehousemen engaged in lawfully transporting or storing narcotic drugs, to any
employee of the common carriers or warehousemen within the scope of employment, to public
officers or employees in the performance of official duties requiring possession or control of narcotic
drugs, or to persons aiding officers or employees in the performance of the duties.

Article V Prohibiting Smoking in Certain Places
Section 19-501 Title. This Ordinance shall be known as the Village of Arlington Heights Clean
Indoor Air Ordinance and shall be in addition to and not be limited by the provisions of any state or
federal legislation, it being the intent of the President and Board of Trustees to enforce the most
restrictive regulations available to curb secondhand smoke.
Ord. #14-031)
Section 19-502 Definitions. The following words and phrases used in this Ordinance shall have the
following meanings:
a. Alternative Nicotine Product. A product or device not consisting of or containing tobacco
that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine, whether by chewing, smoking,
absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing or by any other means. This does not
include tobacco products as that term is defined in this Section or any product approved by
the United States Food and Drug Administration as a non-tobacco product for sale as a
tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence product, or for other medicinal purposes.
b. Enclosed Area. All space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or semi-enclosed with
i) solid walls or windows (exclusive of doorways) which extend from floor to the ceiling, or
ii) solid walls with half wall partitions and no windows (exclusive of doorways) without
limitation to lobbies and corridors.
c. Place of Employment. Any enclosed area under the control of a public or private employer
where one or more employees are required or permitted by an employer to work in the course
of their employment and includes without limitation, work areas, private offices,
auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, cafeterias, elevators, employee
lounges, stairs, hallways, restrooms, medical facilities, private clubs, and the interior of a
vehicle of public conveyance. Aprivate residence is not a “ place of employment” unless the
dwelling is also used partially or exclusively as a day care facility for children or adults, a
HEALTH AND SANITATION
19-18 REVISED 07/07/14
health care facility or a home based business of any kind open to the public provided that
rooms in nursing homes or long-term care facilities occupied by one or more persons who
have requested in writing a room where smoking is permitted shall be considered private
dwelling units.
d. Public Place. Any area that is open to and used by the general public, or any area to which
the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, including without limitations:
1. Vehicles of public conveyance;
2. Common or public areas (including without limitation lobbies, hallways, reception
areas, public restrooms, storage, laundry and elevators) of apartment buildings,
condominiums, dormitory buildings, nursing home care facilities and other multiple
family residential structures;
3. Common or public areas (including without limitation lobbies, hallways, reception
areas, public restrooms, and elevators) or any building or structure that is accessible
to the public including without limitation office, commercial and industrial buildings,
banks and financial institutions, education institutions, health care facilities such as
hospitals, clinics and doctor’ s offices, museums, libraries, restaurants, polling places,
government and Village-owned buildings, food stores, cafeterias, shopping malls,
sports arenas, theaters, auditoriums, public transportation facilities, hotels, motels,
and retail and service establishments;
4. Rooms, chambers, halls, or other locations within which meetings, hearings, or
gatherings are held, to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted,
including specifically, but without limitation, any enclosed area under the control of
the Village of Arlington Heights where there is, in progress, any public meeting.
Provided, however, that “Public Place” shall not include hotel or motel rooms designated as
smoking” provided that no more than 20% of the available rooms for rent in any single
building shall be designated as “ smoking rooms”.
e. Secondhand smoke or involuntary smoking. Amixture of the smoke given off bythe burning
ends of a cigarette, pipe, cigar, bidis, and kreteks (sidestream smoke) and the smoke emitted
at the mouthpiece and exhaled from the lungs of smokers (mainstream smoke) or from any
alternative nicotine product.
f. Smoking. Inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe, weed,
hookah or other lighted tobacco product in any manner or in any form or any alternative
nicotine product
Section 19-503 Prohibition of Smoking in Public Places. Smoking shall be prohibited in all
enclosed public places and places of employment within the Village of Arlington Heights. The
prohibition shall also extend to any enclosed or semi- enclosed sports arena or recreational area,
including sports pavilion, stadium, gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller or
ice rink, bowling alley, and other similar places where members of the general public assemble. It
shall be unlawful for the owner, occupant or lessee in control of the public place to permit smoking
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS MUNICIPAL CODE
19-19 REVISED 02/21/11
in any such public place.
Section 19-504 Prohibition within Distance of Public Places. Smoking is prohibited within 15
feet of any entrance to an enclosed area in which smoking is prohibited and also within 15 feet of any
outdoor eating establishment or facility.
Section 19-505 Exemptions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Ordinance, the following
areas shall be exempted from its provision provided smoking is not limited or prohibited in such
areas under the Illinois Clean Indoor Air Act or federal legislation:
a. Smoking areas incidental to the sale of tobacco in businesses where smoking is confined to
the premises by water pipe or other smoking devices, provided, however, that said smoking
shall take place wholly within such enclosed premises.
b. A private residence as hereinabove defined.
c. Hotel and motel sleeping rooms subject to restrictions as hereinabove set forth.
d. Private and semi-private rooms in nursing homes and long-term care facilities occupied by
one or more persons, all of whom are smokers and have requested in writing to be placed or
to remain as the case may be in a room where smoking is permitted.
e. Smoking by a cast member as part of a performance in a theatrical production.
f. During business hours when wagers are accepted, any facility or property owned, leased or
otherwise operated by a person or entity licensed and regulated by the Illinois State Racing
Board pursuant to the Illinois Horse Racing Act of 1975, 230 ILCS 5/1 et seq. (“ Act”), which
has been approved pursuant to that Act as part of the licensed person’s or entity’s place, track
or enclosure for conducting horse race meetings, or which has been approved pursuant to that
Act to simulcast horse racing and conduct pari-mutuel wagering and is contiguous to the
place, track or enclosure at which horse race meetings take place.
Section 19-506 Posting of Signs. Every public place and place of employment where smoking is
prohibited by this Ordinance shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign indicating “NO
SMOKING”. Such “NOSMOKING” sign shall have a white field with the words “NOSMOKING”
printed in red letters four inches high with a one-half inch face or shall bear the international “NO
SMOKING” symbol which consists of a pictorial representation of a cigarette enclosed in a circle
with a bar across it. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, deface or obscure any sign posted
pursuant to the provisions of this ordinance. The operator, manager, or other person having control
of an area where smoking is prohibited shall remove all ashtrays and other smoking paraphernalia
intended for use where smoking is prohibited.
Section 19-507 Violations and Penalties. Any person who smokes in an area where smoking is
prohibited by this Ordinance shall be punished of a fine of not more than $100. Any person who
owns, manages, operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment who fails to
comply with the provisions of this Ordinance shall be fined not exceeding $100 for the first violation
and $500 for each subsequent offense within one year of the first violation. Each day on which a
violation of this Ordinance occurs shall be considered a separate offense. The Village Manager is
HEALTH AND SANITATION
19-20 REVISED 02/21/11
hereby further authorized to seek an injunction if he determines intentional and repeated violations of
this Ordinance by the owner, manager or person in control of a public place or place of employment
and may commence revocation proceedings for any license issued to a public place subject to
licensing by the Village.

Article VII Penalties
Section 19-701 Penalty.
a. Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any of the provisions of Section 19-203(k)
shall be fined not less than $5 nor more than $750 for each offense; provided, however, that
any person charged with such a violation may, within the time set forth below after the date
of the citation alleging the violation, settle and compromise the charge by paying to the
Village the penalty set forth below:
Within ten days $ 25
After ten days but within 21 days $ 50
In each case in which a compromise payment is made, the Village shall waive further
prosecution of the alleged violation. After 21 days from the date of the citation alleging the
violation, any person who has not settled and compromised the charge shall be given a notice
of date for a court appearance.
b. Any person, firm or corporation who violates any other provisions of this Chapter shall be
fined not less than $5 nor more than $750 for each offense and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during which the violation occurs or is permitted to continue.
